{"uri": "8163593652", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "21:22:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T21:22:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T21:20:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/h5n2-death-mexico-1.7225838", "title": "WHO confirms 1st fatal human case of H5N2 bird flu | CBC News", "body": "Globally, this is the 1st lab-confirmed human case of infection with A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu\n\nThe World Health Organization said on Wednesday that a man in Mexico has died from a subtype of avian influenza, in the first laboratory-confirmed human fatality from the strain.\n\nWHO said the 59-year-old had died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort.\n\nThis was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu reported globally and the first H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals, WHO said. Cases of A(H5N2) subtype of avian influenza have been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\nThe person had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, WHO said.\n\nThis is a different strain of bird flu than H5N1, which sickened dairy cows in 10 U.S. states. {"uri": "8163984317", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:58:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:58:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:57:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/confirms-mexico-mans-death-bird-031015890.html", "title": "WHO confirms Mexico man's death from bird flu strain never before seen in humans", "body": "June 5 (UPI) -- The World Health Organization confirmed Wednesday a man in Mexico has died from a strain of bird flu called H5N2, in what is the first laboratory-confirmed case of that strain in a human.\n\nWhile cases of A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico, the 59-year-old victim had had no exposure to poultry or other animals, according to WHO. There have been a total of three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in Mexico as scientists have so far been unable to find a connection to the victim who died April 24.\n\nThe man was hospitalized in Mexico City with a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea and nausea, according to WHO. His relatives reported he \"had already been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms.\"\n\nThe U.N. agency said lab results confirmed it was the first human H5 virus infection reported in Mexico and the first human death of someone infected with the avian influenza subtype H5N2.\n\nMexico's health ministry issued a statement Wednesday saying the man, who officials did not identify, had several underlying medical conditions before contracting the strain. The ministry said all people who had contact with him have tested negative with no evidence of person-to-person transmission.\n\nAt this point, the risk of the bird flu virus to Mexico's general population is low. \"This case does not change the current WHO recommendations on public health measures and surveillance of influenza,\" according to the health organization.\n\nThe bird flu strain in Mexico, H5N2, is unrelated to the strain of bird flu in the United States, called H5N1 that infected three dairy farm workers who were exposed to cattle.\n\nLast week, CSL Seqirus announced it is preparing nearly 5 million doses of vaccine against H5N1 avian flu for possible use in humans \"later this summer.\" The new vaccine combines an antigen that targets the H5 portion of H5N1 with an ingredient to boost the immune response.\n\nWhile the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says the risk to public health is low as human cases of bird flu in the United States are rare, they {"uri": "8164065749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:07:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:07:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:05:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2024/06/06/news/regional/person-with-bird-flu-died-in-mexico-who-says/", "title": "Person with bird flu died in Mexico, WHO says - Stabroek News", "body": "(Reuters) - A person with prior health complications who had contracted bird flu died in Mexico in April and the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico had been hospitalized in Mexico City and died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nIt was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly.\"\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state. {"uri": "2024-06-380282127", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "02:30:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T02:30:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T02:23:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/mexico-man-dies-bird-flu-022350618.html", "title": "Mexico man dies of bird flu strain never before detected in humans", "body": "A man's death in Mexico was caused by a strain of bird flu called H5N2 that has never before been found in a human, the World Health Organisation (WHO) announced on Wednesday evening.\n\nThe H5N2 strain has previously been reported in poultry but the 59-year-old who was hospitalised in Mexico City had not been in contact with infected chickens or other animals.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO wrote in a statement.\n\n\"According to the IHR (2005), a human infection caused by a novel influenza A virus subtype is an event that has the potential for high public health impact and must be notified to the WHO. Based on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low.\n\nThere are numerous types of bird flu. H5N2 is not the same as the H5N1 strain that has resulted in three farm workers in the United States becoming ill in recent months.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the US.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO statement read, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Mexico's public health department said in a statement that he had underlying ailments, including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHospital care was sought on April 24 and the man died the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.\n\nNo further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March but authorities haven't been able to find a connection. Mexican officials also are monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu {"uri": "8163672864", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:47:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:47:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:47:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/06/05/breaking-news/who-confirms-fatal-human-case-of-bird-flu-in-mexico/", "title": "WHO confirms fatal human case of bird flu in Mexico | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Test tubes labeled \"Bird Flu\" and a piece of paper in the colors of the U.S. national flag are seen in this picture illustration, in January 2023. The World Health Organization today said a person's death was caused by the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with the A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu reported globally, and the first human infection with the H5 strain of the virus reported in Mexico.\n\nThe World Health Organization today said a person's death was caused by the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with the A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu reported globally, and the first human infection with the H5 strain of the virus reported in Mexico.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico, who had been hospitalized in Mexico City, died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals, but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the United Nations agency said.\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state, but said at the time this did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nBased on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low.\n\nNo further cases have been reported during an investigation that tested people who had come into contact with the victim for types of influenza, as well as for COVID-19, it said.\n\nCases of bird flu have now been identified in mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two just had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.", "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Honolulu Star Advertiser"}, "authors": {"uri": "8164301410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:48:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:48:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:48:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/first-human-death-bird-flu-mexico-h5n2-b2557755.html", "title": "Mexican man dies from first human infection of H5N2 bird flu", "body": "The 59-year-old man died on 24 April after being admitted to a Mexico City hospital with multiple underlying medical conditions.\n\nHe was admitted after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general discomfort on 17 April, the WHO said.\n\nThe source of the infection was not yet known, the UN agency said.\n\nAlthough H5N2 viruses have been found in poultry in Mexico, indicating a potential link, the deceased person had no known history of exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\n\"This is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A (H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico,\" the WHO said, adding that current risk to the general population from the virus was low.\n\nMexico's health ministry said there was no evidence the virus was transmitted person-to-person.\n\nAll people linked to the deceased man were tested for the flu virus but none of them had it, the ministry added.\n\nThe man had prior health conditions, including chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes, and was bedridden for three weeks before the onset of acute symptoms.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nMexico has reported three poultry outbreaks of H5N2, most recently in March, but they were found to be unrelated to the outbreak of a different strain of bird flu in the US which infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nScientists around the world are on alert for any changes in the virus that may indicate bird flu is evolving to spread more readily among humans.\n\nOther strains of bird flu have killed a number of people across the world in recent years. As many as 18 people were killed in China in 2021 after the outbreak of H5N6, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nAustralia reported its first infection of H5N1 in May H5N2 is Several dairy herds affected In the United States, the strain is called H5N1. Three Farm Workers I have a mild infection.\n\nOther types of bird flu have killed people around the world in the past, including the 2021 H5N6 influenza outbreak in China, which killed 18 people, according to a timeline of bird flu epidemics in the United States. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old man who died in a Mexico City hospital had been infected with the virus despite having no history of contact with poultry or other animals.\n\nThe WHO statement said that according to family members, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Mexico's Public Health Agency said in a statement that the patient had underlying conditions including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHe was treated at a hospital on April 24 but died the same day.\n\nInitial tests detected an unknown type of influenza, but laboratory tests over the next few weeks confirmed it was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to the Mexican population was low and that no new cases had been found so far, despite testing people who had come into contact with the dead at home and in hospital.\n\nThere were three outbreaks of H5N2 avian influenza in poultry near Mexico in March, but authorities have not found a link. Mexican authorities are also monitoring birds near a shallow lake outside Mexico City.\n\nIf avian flu spreads among poultry, people in close contact with the flocks are at risk of infection. Health officials are closely watching for signs that the virus is evolving to spread more easily from person to person, and experts are concerned that more mammal species are infected with the avian flu virus.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science Education Media Group. {"uri": "8163847401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "02:34:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T02:34:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T02:33:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/who-confirms-worlds-first-human-bird-flu-death-in-mexico-2549633-2024-06-06", "title": "WHO confirms world's first human bird flu death in Mexico", "body": "first laboratory-confirmed human case of A(H5N2) virus infection\n\nA person with prior health complications who had contracted bird flu died in Mexico in April and the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico had been hospitalised in Mexico City and died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico\", WHO said in a statement.\n\nIt was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu\", said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly\".\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state. The government said the cases did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission in the case and farms near the victim's home were monitored.\n\nOther people in contact with the person tested negative for bird flu, the health ministry and the WHO said.\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans\", Pekosz said.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has, however, found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "India Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": in Mexico", "body": "The World Health Organization on Wednesday said a person's death was caused by the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with the A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu reported globally, and the first human infection with the H5 strain of the virus reported in Mexico.\n\nThe 59-year-old, who had been hospitalized in Mexico City, died April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals, but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the United Nations agency said.\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state, but said at the time this did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nBased on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low.\n\nNo further cases have been reported during an investigation that tested people who had come into contact with the victim for types of influenza, as well as for COVID-19, it said.\n\nCases of bird flu have now been identified in mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is {"uri": "8163680147", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:58:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:58:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:57:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://en-volve.com/2024/06/05/just-in-world-health-organization-claims-death-in-mexico-linked-to-bird-flu-strain/", "title": "JUST IN: World Health Organization Claims Death In Mexico Linked To Bird Flu Strain", "body": "From 100PercentFedUp - READ ORIGINAL\n\nSome media, including videos, may only be available to view at the original.\n\nShare this:\n\nThe World Health Organization claimed an individual's death in Mexico was due to the \"first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus.\"\n\n\"On 23 May 2024, the Mexico International Health Regulations (IHR) National Focal Point (NFP) reported to PAHO/WHO a confirmed fatal case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N2) virus detected in a resident of the State of Mexico who was hospitalized in Mexico City. This is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico,\" the WHO stated.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico. According to the IHR (2005), a human infection caused by a novel influenza A virus subtype is an event that has the potential for high public health impact and must be notified to the WHO. Based on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low,\" it added.\n\nThe patient, a 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico, had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\n\"The case had multiple underlying medical conditions. The case's relatives reported that the case had already been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms,\" the WHO stated.\n\nPer Reuters:\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state, but said at the time this did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nBased on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low.\n\nThe United States has reported three human cases of bird flu in recent months.\n\nThird Reported American Bird Flu Case, CDC Issues Statement", "source": {"uri": "en-volve.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "enVolve"}, "authors": [{"uri": "a_m_smith@en-volve.com", "name": "A.M. {"uri": "2024-06-380441633", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:25:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:25:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:01:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.telegraphindia.com/world/first-human-death-from-bird-flu-reported-in-mexico-says-world-health-organization/cid/2024963", "title": "First human death from bird flu reported in Mexico, source of exposure to virus unknown: WHO", "body": "Scientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers\n\nA person with prior health complications who had contracted bird flu died in Mexico in April and the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico had been hospitalized in Mexico City and died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nIt was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly.\"\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state. The government said the cases did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission in the case and farms near the victim's home were monitored.\n\nOther people in contact with the person tested negative for bird flu, the health ministry and the WHO said.\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" Pekosz said.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.", "source": {"uri": "telegraphindia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Telegraph"}, "authors": [{"uri": had contracted bird flu died in Mexico in April and the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nIt was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly.\"\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state. The government said the cases did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission in the case and farms near the victim's home were monitored.\n\nOther people in contact with the person tested negative for bird flu, the health ministry and the WHO said.\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" Pekosz said.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.", "source": {"uri": "adaderana.lk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Ada Derana"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "https://adaderanaenglish.s3.amazonaws.com/1717672567-Bird-flu-large.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9628348", "eventUri": "eng-9628348", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": {"uri": "2024-06-380224689", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:25:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:25:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-06-05/person-with-bird-flu-died-in-mexico-who-says", "title": "Person With Bird Flu Died in Mexico, WHO Says", "body": "A drone view shows the Institute of Epidemiological Diagnosis and Reference after the World Health Organization said a person's death was caused by the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with the A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu reported globally, and the first human infection with the H5 strain of the virus reported in Mexico, in Mexico City, Mexico June 5, 2024. REUTERS/Daniel Becerril\n\n(Reuters) -A person with prior health complications who had contracted bird flu died in Mexico in April and the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico had been hospitalized in Mexico City and died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nIt was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly.\"\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state. The government said the cases did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission in the case and farms near the victim's home were monitored.\n\nOther people in contact with the person tested negative for bird flu, the health ministry and the WHO said.\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" Pekosz said.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.\n\n(Reporting by Urvi Dugar and Puyaan Singh in Bengaluru, Ana Isabel Martinez and Sarah Morland in Mexico City; Writing by Caroline Stauffer; Editing by Richard Chang, Bill Berkrot and Lisa Shumaker)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8163757448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:36:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:36:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T00:34:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/world/2024/06/501_376084.html", "title": "WHO confirms fatal human case of bird flu in Mexico", "body": "Talita de Lima Freitas, federal agricultural inspector, works on a sample to test for avian influenza virus at the Reference Laboratory of the World Organization for Animal Health in Campinas, Brazil April 25, 2023. Reuters-Yonhap\n\nThe World Health Organization on Wednesday said a person's death was caused by the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with the A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu reported globally, and the first human infection with the H5 strain of the virus reported in Mexico.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico, who had been hospitalized in Mexico City, died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals, but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the United Nations agency said.\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state, but said at the time this did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nBased on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low.\n\nNo further cases have been reported during an investigation that tested people who had come into contact with the victim for types of influenza, as well as for COVID-19, it said.\n\nCases of bird flu have now been identified in mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two just had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. {"uri": "8163991118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:05:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:05:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:03:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/585016", "title": "Person with bird flu died in Mexico, WHO says", "body": "A person with prior health complications who had contracted bird flu died in Mexico in April and the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico had been hospitalized in Mexico City and died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said\n\nIt was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nALSO READ: Bird flu infects third US dairy worker; Michigan set to expand testing\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly\".\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state. The government said the cases did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission in the case and farms near the victim's home were monitored\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission in the case and farms near the victim's home were monitored.\n\nOther people in contact with the person tested negative for bird flu, the health ministry and the WHO said.\n\nALSO READ: H5N1 bird flu detected in US San Francisco\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" Pekosz said.\n\nREAD MORE: H7 bird flu found on third poultry farm in Australia\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. {"uri": "8163878117", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "03:11:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T03:11:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T03:11:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/man-in-mexico-dies-from-first-human-case-of-bird-flu-strain-h5n2-13779306.html", "title": "Man in Mexico dies from first human case of bird flu strain H5N2", "body": "FILE - The logo of the World Health Organization is seen at the WHO headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland. - AP\n\nA man died in Mexico from a strain of bird flu called H5N2 that has never before been found in a human, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). The mode of infection remains unclear, the WHO said on Wednesday adding that (H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\nScientists are now on high alert for any changes in the virus that might indicate it is adapting to spread more easily among humans. There are numerous types of bird flu. H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old man who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Mexico's public health department said in a statement that he had underlying ailments, including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHospital care was sought on April 24 and the man died the same day. Initial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to people in Mexico is low, and that no further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital. There had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March but authorities haven't been able to find a connection. Mexican officials also are monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu Experts see little risk Bird flu pushes US dairy farmers to ban visitors, chop trees Bird flu detected in alpacas in US for the first time Bird flu viral fragments found in pasteurized milk\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe resident of the State of Mexico was hospitalised in Mexico City and died the same day, the statement said.\n\nIt was the \"first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally\", the WHO added.\n\nMexican health authorities reported the confirmed case to the UN health body on May 23 after conducting laboratory tests.\n\nThe source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the WHO said, although cases of H5N2 have been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\nH5N2 cases were detected in a backyard poultry farm in Michoacan state in March, with other outbreaks identified in the State of Mexico, according to the UN health body.\n\nChronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes\n\nBut it said establishing a link between the human case and the poultry infections was so far impossible, estimating the risk to people as \"low\".\n\nMexico's health ministry said in a statement that the person who died was \"a 59-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, (and) long-standing systemic arterial hypertension\".\n\n\"There is no risk of contagion for the population,\" the statement said, adding that \"all samples from identified contacts (of the patient) have been negative\".\n\nAuthorities are monitoring farms near the victim's home and have established a permanent monitoring system to detect other cases in wildlife in the area, the statement added.\n\nA different variant of bird flu, H5N1, has been spreading for weeks among dairy cow herds in the United States, with a small number of cases reported among humans.\n\nBut none of the cases are human-to-human infections, with the disease instead jumping from cattle to people, authorities have said.\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" Pekosz said.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. {"uri": "2024-06-380548635", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:11:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:11:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:18:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.medicaldaily.com/man-mexico-dies-bird-flu-first-human-case-h5n2-virus-who-471829", "title": "Man In Mexico Dies From Bird Flu; First Human Case Of H5N2 Virus: WHO", "body": "A man in Mexico has died from a strain of bird flu infection that has been detected for the first time in humans, WHO said.\n\nA 59-year-old Mexican resident was hospitalized on April 24 with signs of fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea, and discomfort. The patient, who had already been bedridden for weeks with multiple other underlying conditions, died from the complications. The sample taken after his death tested positive for influenza A (H5N2).\n\n\"This is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico,\" WHO said in a news release.\n\nAlthough the strain H5N2 had earlier been detected in poultry in Mexico, the source from which the patient contracted the fatal infection is not known, as he did not have any contact with poultry.\n\nMexico's health ministry confirmed that there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission of bird flu in the case of the man who died. All people who had contact with the patient tested negative for the virus.\n\n\"According to the information available thus far, no further human cases of infection with A(H5N2) associated with this case have been detected...Based on the available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus to be low,\" the WHO news release read.\n\nScientists assure that the current case detected in Mexico is unrelated to the bird flu outbreak in the U.S. Three dairy farm workers in the U.S. have been infected so far with the bird flu virus after the H5N1 virus was detected in cows across several states in the country.\n\nWhile the current case does not change the WHO's recommendations regarding bird flu, the health organization stresses the importance of global surveillance. It is crucial \"to detect and monitor virological, epidemiological and clinical changes associated with emerging or circulating influenza viruses that may affect human and animal health and timely virus-sharing for risk assessment.\"\n\nThe WHO recommends travelers to countries experiencing animal influenza outbreaks avoid farms, direct contact with animals, and surfaces potentially contaminated with animal feces. ( Image Source :Representational Image/ Getty )\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) has said that a Mexican man died in April from a strain of bird flu (H5N2) that has never been detected in humans. According to The Guardian, on Wednesday, the WHO said it doesn't know how the man got infected with the virus.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" it said in a statement. Scientists, the report said, are closely monitoring any mutations in the virus that may indicate it's adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nHowever, the UN agency said the current risk from bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old Mexican man, who suffered from prior health complications, was hospitalised in Mexico City, and died on April 24, after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general discomfort, the WHO said, as quoted in a Reuters report. According to the WHO, this marked the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico.\n\nIn a statement, Mexico's health ministry stated that there had been no evidence of person-to-person transmission of bird flu in the case of the man, and that he had several prior health conditions. Mexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes. They tested all the people he was in contact with and they all tested negative.\n\nAndrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University, told Reuters that how the man was infected was the \"big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly\".\n\nIn May, Australia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection, noting there were no signs of transmission, Guardian reported. It has, however, found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state, Reuters reported.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. {"uri": "2024-06-380448025", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:33:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:33:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:32:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://rsoe-edis.org/eventList/details/637445/0", "title": "Infection hazard - Mexico - Person with first human case of bird flu strain dies in Mexico, WHO confirms", "body": "A person with prior health complications who contracted the first human case of a subtype of bird flu has died in Mexico City, says the World Health Organization.\n\nThe 59-year-old died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said in a statement on Wednesday, local time.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu to the general population is low.\n\nIt is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with the H5N2 strain of bird flu, also known as avian influenza, reported globally, and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said the source of infection in the victim from Mexico City had not been identified, but so far no evidence of person-to-person transmission has occurred.\n\nThe man had several prior health conditions, the ministry said in a statement, and all people who had contact with him have tested negative.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nLast week Victorian health officials confirmed Australia's first human case of one particular strain of the bird flu, H5N1 avian influenza, which was detected in a child travelling home to Victoria from India.\n\nThe same strain, which scientists also say is unrelated to the case in Mexico, has so far infected three dairy farm workers in the US.\n\nUS nearing deal to fund bird flu vaccine, report says\n\nThe US government is nearing an agreement to fund a late-stage trial of Moderna's mRNA bird flu vaccine, the Financial Times reported.\n\nModerna told Reuters it was in discussions with the government on advancing its vaccine candidate, but did not confirm the funding.\n\nThe company said it was testing the experimental shot, mRNA-1018, against several strains of the virus -- including the currently circulating H5N1 variant.\n\nReuters/ABC", "source": {"uri": "rsoe-edis.org", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8165153983", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:53:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:53:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:52:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.medscape.com/s/viewarticle/person-bird-flu-died-mexico-who-says-2024a1000alm", "title": "Person With Bird Flu Died in Mexico, WHO Says", "body": "(Reuters) -A person with prior health complications who had contracted bird flu died in Mexico in April and the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico had been hospitalized in Mexico City and died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nIt was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly.\"\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state. The government said the cases did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission in the case and farms near the victim's home were monitored.\n\nOther people in contact with the person tested negative for bird flu, the health ministry and the WHO said.\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" Pekosz said.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.\n\n(Reporting by Urvi Dugar and Puyaan Singh in Bengaluru, Ana Isabel Martinez and Sarah Morland in Mexico City; {"uri": "8164292501", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:43:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:43:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:42:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/man-in-mexico-died-from-first-human-case-of-h5n2-bird-flu-who-confirms-5663623", "title": "Man in Mexico Died From First Human Case of H5N2 Bird Flu, WHO Confirms", "body": "The World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed on Wednesday the first known case of a human death resulting from an infection with the A(H5N2) variant of avian influenza, also known as bird flu.\n\nThe individual, a 59-year-old resident of Mexico, first developed a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea, and a general feeling of discomfort on April 17, according to the public health agency.\n\nHe was subsequently hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases in Mexico City on April 24 and died later that day.\n\nTesting conducted on the day he was hospitalized indicated the individual had a \"non-subtypeable influenza A virus\" and further testing led to a positive sample for influenza A(H5N2), the UN agency said.\n\nThe individual had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals at the time of his hospitalization, the WHO noted.\n\nHowever, the man had prior health complications including multiple underlying medical conditions, and relatives told hospital staff that he had been bedridden for three weeks before his admission for \"other reasons.\"\n\nMexico's health ministry said in a statement that the person had chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, and systemic hypertension.\n\nIt spreads easily among birds through nasal and eye secretions, as well as manure, and it can prove deadly in domestic poultry.\n\nWhile it is unclear how the Mexico resident became infected, multiple cases of avian influenza have been reported in the country in recent months, including one outbreak detected in a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoac\u00e1n in March.\n\nAnother outbreak was identified in March in poultry in Texcoco, in the State of Mexico, and another in April in the municipality of Temascalapa in the same state, the health body said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" the WHO said Wednesday.\n\nThe latest discovery marks the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico, according to the UN body.\n\nNo further cases of the virus were reported during an epidemiological investigation into the latest case. Seventeen people who were at the hospital where the man died were monitored, with health officials only reporting a runny nose in one of them between April 28-29.\n\nAdditionally, 12 other people were identified as having been \"near\" the man's home before his hospitalization and death, according to the WHO.\n\nSeven of those people were symptomatic and five asymptomatic, however, all of those individuals subsequently tested negative for SARS-CoV-2, influenza A, and influenza B.\n\nDespite the man's death, the UN agency said Wednesday that -- based on available information -- the current risk to the general population posed by this virus is low.\n\nThe WHO also said the case is unrelated to a different outbreak of bird flu, H5N1, that has been detected in the United States, although both are H5 avian viruses.\n\nAlong with the United States and Mexico, Australia has also reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection this year, with health officials stating in May that there were no signs of transmission.\n\nHealth officials in the country have, however, found additional poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", {"uri": "2024-06-380475156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:02:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:02:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:47:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/world/first-human-death-bird-flu-h5n2-mexico-3094651", "title": "First human death from H5N2 bird flu confirmed by World Health Organisation", "body": "WHO said the risk of the virus to the general population is low based on available information.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico had been hospitalised in Mexico City and died on 24 April after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\nThe source of the individual's exposure to the virus is not known.\n\nIn a statement the WHO said: \"This is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico.\"\n\nIn March 2024, a high pathogenicity avian influenza A(H5N2) outbreak was detected in a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoac\u00e1n, which borders the State of Mexico where the case was residing, the WHO said in a statement.\n\nThe fatal bird flu case had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the individual had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University told Reuters.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly\", he added.\n\nAn investigation identified no other cases, with 17 people in contact with the person at the hospital where they died and 12 near their residence testing negative, the WHO said.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of H5N1 infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.\n\nIn January, a British-led team of scientists identified the highly contagious H5N1 virus in the sub-Antarctica region for the first time - in dead elephant and fur seals on the island of South Georgia.\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect {"uri": "8164482914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:37:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:37:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:36:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/684229/international/who-records-first-fatal-human-case-of-bird-flu", "title": "WHO records first fatal human case of bird flu", "body": "The World Health Organization (WHO) announced a death caused by the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with a subtype of avian influenza (bird flu).\n\nWHO confirmed in a statement that the first human infection with avian influenza A (H5N2) virus was recorded, which led to the death of the infected man in Mexico, after suffering from fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea, and general fatigue.\n\nThis is the world's first case of laboratory-confirmed human infection with the A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu, and the first case of infection with the H5 virus among humans in Mexico.\n\nThe person had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals, WHO said.\n\nCases of A(H5N2) subtype of the bird flu have been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\nSince late 2021, Europe has been witnessing the worst outbreak of bird flu ever, while North and South America have also witnessed a severe outbreak, and this has led to the killing of tens of millions of poultry around the world, many of which carry the H5N1 virus strain. H5N1 first appeared in 1996.\n\nBird flu infection in humans is rare, but when it occurs it can cause severe illness with a high death rate, as infection with the virus in humans usually results from direct or indirect exposure to infected live or dead poultry or contaminated environments. {"uri": "8164461853", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:24:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:24:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:23:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/man-in-mexico-died-from-first-human-case-of-h5n2-bird-flu-who-confirms_997950.html", "title": "Man in Mexico Died From First Human Case of H5N2 Bird Flu, WHO Confirms", "body": "A drone view shows the Institute of Epidemiological Diagnosis and Reference in Mexico City, Mexico, on June 5, 2024. (Daniel Becerril/Reuters)\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed on Wednesday the first known case of a human death resulting from an infection with the A(H5N2) variant of avian influenza, also known as bird flu.\n\nThe individual, a 59-year-old resident of Mexico, first developed a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea, and a general feeling of discomfort on April 17, according to the public health agency.\n\nHe was subsequently hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases in Mexico City on April 24 and died later that day.\n\nTesting conducted on the day he was hospitalized indicated the individual had a \"non-subtypeable influenza A virus\" and further testing led to a positive sample for influenza A(H5N2), the UN agency said.\n\nThe individual had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals at the time of his hospitalization, the WHO noted.\n\nHowever, the man had prior health complications including multiple underlying medical conditions, and relatives told hospital staff that he had been bedridden for three weeks before his admission for \"other reasons.\"\n\nMexico's health ministry said in a statement that the person had chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, and systemic hypertension.\n\nThe Epoch Times has contacted the WHO for further comment.\n\nAvian influenza, or bird flu, is a highly contagious viral disease that primarily affects birds. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the disease has also been found in other animals, such as pigs and dogs in China, Indonesia, and Vietnam, as well as domestic cats in Germany.\n\nIt spreads easily among birds through nasal and eye secretions, as well as manure, and it can prove deadly in domestic poultry.\n\nWhile it is unclear how the Mexico resident became infected, multiple cases of avian influenza have been reported in the country in recent months, including one outbreak detected in a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoac\u00e1n in March.\n\nAnother outbreak was identified in March in poultry in Texcoco, in the State of Mexico, and another in April in the municipality of Temascalapa in the same state, the health body said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" the WHO said Wednesday.\n\nThe latest discovery marks the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico, according to the UN body.\n\nNo further cases of the virus were reported during an epidemiological investigation into the latest case. Seventeen people who were at the hospital where the man died were monitored, with health officials only reporting a runny nose in one of them between April 28-29.\n\nNone of those individuals tested positive for influenza or SARS-CoV 2, the healthy body noted.\n\nAdditionally, 12 other people were identified as having been \"near\" the man's home before his hospitalization and death, according to the WHO.\n\nSeven of those people were symptomatic and five asymptomatic, however, all of those individuals subsequently tested negative for SARS-CoV-2, influenza A, and influenza B.\n\nDespite the man's death, the UN agency said Wednesday that -- based on available information -- the current risk to the general population posed by this virus is low.\n\nThe WHO also said the case is unrelated to a different outbreak of bird flu, H5N1, that has been detected in the United States, although both are H5 avian viruses.\n\nThat outbreak has so far infected three individuals; all of whom were dairy farm workers.\n\nAlong with the United States and Mexico, Australia has also reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection this year, with health officials stating in May that there were no signs of transmission.\n\nHealth officials in the country have, however, found additional poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8163672453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:47:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:47:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:46:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://100percentfedup.com/just-world-health-organization-claims-death-mexico-linked/", "title": "JUST IN: World Health Organization Claims Death In Mexico Linked To Bird Flu Strain * 100PercentFedUp.com * by Danielle", "body": "The World Health Organization claimed an individual's death in Mexico was due to the \"first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus.\"\n\n\"On 23 May 2024, the Mexico International Health Regulations (IHR) National Focal Point (NFP) reported to PAHO/WHO a confirmed fatal case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N2) virus detected in a resident of the State of Mexico who was hospitalized in Mexico City. This is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico,\" the WHO stated.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico. According to the IHR (2005), a human infection caused by a novel influenza A virus subtype is an event that has the potential for high public health impact and must be notified to the WHO. Based on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low,\" it added.\n\nThe patient, a 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico, had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\n\"The case had multiple underlying medical conditions. The case's relatives reported that the case had already been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms,\" the WHO stated.\n\nIn March, Mexico's government health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nBased on available information, WHO assesses the current
