{"uri": "8163998674", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:09:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:09:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.thailandmedical.news/news/mexico-had-a-h5n2-outbreak-in-march-with-one-death-in-april-but-who-only-tells-the-world-now", "title": "Mexico Had A H5N2 Outbreak In March With One Death In April But WHO Only Tells The World Now! - Thailand Medical News", "body": "H5N2 News: A Sudden Revelation\n\nIn a recent development, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced the first human death from the H5N2 strain of bird flu in Mexico. This news, released on June 5th, 2024, has shocked many, considering the outbreak occurred in March and the individual succumbed to the virus in April. The delay in reporting this case has raised concerns and questions about the transparency and efficiency of health communications in times of crisis.\n\nMexico Had A H5N2 Outbreak In March With One Death In April\n\nIt is also interesting to note that none of the stupid mainstream media in the West that covered this H5N2 News outbreak after WHO's released their report the last 36 hours questioned as to why the world is only knowing about this H5N2 outbreak that started since March 2024!\n\nThe Outbreak and Its Aftermath\n\nThe outbreak of H5N2 bird flu was first detected in a poultry farm in Michoacan state, Mexico, in March 2024. Despite the outbreak being reported promptly to the local authorities, it was not considered a threat to human health or distant commercial farms at that time. However, the situation took a drastic turn when a 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico contracted the virus and subsequently died.\n\nThe Victim's Health and Hospitalization\n\nThe deceased, who had multiple underlying health conditions, including chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes, had been bedridden for three weeks prior to developing symptoms of bird flu. In mid-April, the patient experienced fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea, and general discomfort. Despite receiving medical attention and being hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases in Mexico City, the individual passed away on April 24th.\n\nUnknown Source of Infection\n\nOne of the most alarming aspects of this case is the unknown source of the infection. The victim had no known exposure to poultry or other animals, which makes the origin of the virus particularly concerning.\n\nWHO's statement highlighted that although H5N2 viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico, the specific route of transmission in this case remains a mystery.\n\nhttps://www.who.int/emergencies/disease-outbreak-news/item/2024-DON520\n\nThis raises significant questions about how the virus could have infected a human without direct contact with infected birds.\n\nThe Global Context: H5N2 and H5N1\n\nWhile Mexico grapples with this H5N2 case, it's worth noting the broader context of bird flu globally. The H5N1 strain of bird flu has been causing outbreaks in the United States, particularly affecting dairy farm workers. Since March 2024, three cases of H5N1 human infection have been reported in the U.S., with symptoms ranging from conjunctiviti s to respiratory issues. Although the H5N2 strain in Mexico and the H5N1 strain in the U.S. are different, both highlight the persistent threat of avian influenza viruses crossing species barriers and infecting humans.\n\nMonitoring and Vigilance\n\nScientists have long warned about the potential for bird flu viruses to mutate and spread more easily among humans. Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University, emphasized the need for vigilance, stating that H5 viruses have shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus since 1997. Every spillover event, he noted, is an opportunity for the virus to adapt and potentially become more transmissible among humans.\n\nThe Response and Future Precautions\n\nFollowing the death in Mexico, it was claimed that the Health Ministry and WHO took immediate steps to monitor and contain the situation. Farms near the victim's home were monitored, and individuals who had been in contact with the deceased were tested for bird flu, with all results returning negative. Despite these measures, the case underscores the importance of robust surveillance systems and rapid response mechanisms to detect and contain new infections promptly.\n\nGlobal Implications\n\nThe first human case of H5N2 bird flu in Mexico is a stark reminder of the ongoing challenges posed by zoonotic diseases - those that can jump from animals to humans. Bird flu viruses typically circulate in birds but can occasionally infect humans through direct contact with infected animals or contaminated environments. These infections can lead to a range of symptoms from mild respiratory issues to severe, potentially fatal illnesses.\n\nConcluding Thoughts\n\nThe revelation of this H5N2 case months after the initial outbreak highlights a critical need for timely and transparent communication from health authorities. As the world continues to battle various strains of bird flu and other zoonotic diseases, global health agencies must prioritize swift reporting and effective containment strategies to mitigate the risks posed by these viruses. The case in Mexico serves as a sobering reminder of the importance of vigilance, preparedness, and international cooperation in managing public health threats.\n\nFor the latest H5N2 News, keep on logging to Thailand Medical News.\n\nRead {"uri": "8163652265", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "22:23:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T22:23:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T22:22:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/health/2973293-first-global-human-case-of-ah5n2-bird-flu-confirmed-fatal-in-mexico", "title": "First Global Human Case of A(H5N2) Bird Flu Confirmed Fatal in Mexico | Health", "body": "The WHO confirmed the first human death from the A(H5N2) bird flu, a 59-year-old in Mexico. Despite no direct poultry contact, underlying conditions contributed to the fatality. With low general risk, no further cases were found. Other strains like H5N1 have also surfaced elsewhere, heightening vigilance.\n\n(Adds detail, background throughout) June 5 (Reuters) -\n\nThe World Health Organization on Wednesday said a person's death was caused by the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with the A(H5N2) subtype of bird flu reported globally, and the first human infection with the H5 strain of the virus reported in Mexico. The 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico, who had been hospitalized in Mexico City, died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement. The victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals, but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the United Nations agency said.\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state, but said at the time this did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health. After the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nBased on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low. No further cases have been reported during an investigation that tested people who had come into contact with the victim for types of influenza, as well as for COVID-19, it said.\n\nCases of bird flu have now been identified in mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds. Scientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two just had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms. Australia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "8164680138", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:35:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:35:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:34:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/health-fitness/health-news/first-human-bird-flu-death-can-it-spread-from-human-to-human/articleshow/110766294.cms", "title": "First human bird flu death: Can it spread from human to human? - Times of India", "body": "The World Health Organisation (WHO) on Wednesday confirmed the death of a 59 year old man due to bird flu. \"On 23 May 2024, the Mexico IHR NFP reported to PAHO/WHO a confirmed case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N2) virus detected in a 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico who was hospitalized in Mexico City and had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals.The case had multiple underlying medical conditions. The case's relatives reported that the case had already been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms,\" WHO has said in a press release.\n\nNow, with the first human death of bird flu a big and threatening question arises: Can bird flu virus be passed on from one infected human to another?\n\n\"No evidence, so far\"\n\nThere has so far been no evidence of person-to-person transmission of bird flu in the case of a man who died from the disease in Mexico, the nation's health ministry said on Wednesday. The man had several prior health conditions, the ministry said in a statement, and all people who had contact with him have tested negative.\n\nThe WHO's press release says, 17 contacts of the deceased person were identified and monitored at the hospital out of which one reported a runny nose between 28 and 29 April. Samples taken from these hospital contacts between 27 and 29 May tested negative for influenza and SARS-CoV 2, the WHO has said. Twelve additional contacts (seven symptomatic and five asymptomatic) which were identified near the case's residence were also found to be negative for flu.\n\nThe Mexico health ministry has confirmed that bird flu detected does not represent risk to the population. It also says that the source of infection in this case has not been identified.\n\nH5N2 bird flu\n\nIn March 2024, a high pathogenicity avian influenza A(H5N2) outbreak was detected in a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoac\u00e1n, which borders the State of Mexico where the case was residing, the WHO has said.\n\nH5N2 is a subtype of the avian influenza virus, primarily affecting birds, including domestic poultry and wild waterfowl. It is a highly pathogenic strain, meaning it can cause severe disease and high mortality rates in infected bird populations. While H5N2 primarily poses a threat to the poultry industry, causing significant economic losses, it has a low risk of transmission to humans. Effective biosecurity practices and surveillance are essential in managing H5N2 outbreaks.\n\n(With inputs from Reuters, AP)", "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-06-380224673", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:25:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:25:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:39:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/health/person-in-mexico-died-of-a-bird-flu-strain-that-hadnt-been-confirmed-before-in-a-human-who-says/", "title": "Man in Mexico died of a bird flu strain that hadn't been confirmed before in a human, WHO says", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- A man's death in Mexico was caused by a strain of bird flu called H5N2 that has never before been found in a human, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.\n\nThe WHO said it wasn't clear how the man became infected, although H5N2 has been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\nThere are numerous types of bird flu. H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old man who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Mexico's public health department said in a statement that he had underlying ailments, including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHospital care was sought on April 24 and the man died the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to people in Mexico is low, and that no further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March but authorities haven't been able to find a connection. Mexican officials also are monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu viruses.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. {"uri": "2024-06-380706852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:26:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:26:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:17:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/man-in-mexico-died-from-first-human-case-of-h5n2-bird-flu-who-confirms_997950.html?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter", "title": "Man in Mexico Died From First Human Case of H5N2 Bird Flu, WHO Confirms", "body": "The World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed on Wednesday the first known case of a human death resulting from an infection with the A(H5N2) variant of avian influenza, also known as bird flu.\n\nThe individual, a 59-year-old resident of Mexico, first developed a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea, and a general feeling of discomfort on April 17, according to the public health agency.\n\nHe was subsequently hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases in Mexico City on April 24 and died later that day.\n\nTesting conducted on the day he was hospitalized indicated the individual had a \"non-subtypeable influenza A virus\" and further testing led to a positive sample for influenza A(H5N2), the UN agency said.\n\nThe individual had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals at the time of his hospitalization, the WHO noted.\n\nHowever, the man had prior health complications including multiple underlying medical conditions, and relatives told hospital staff that he had been bedridden for three weeks before his admission for \"other reasons.\"\n\nMexico's health ministry said in a statement that the person had chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, and systemic hypertension.\n\nThe Epoch Times has contacted the WHO for further comment.\n\nWhat Is Avian Influenza?\n\nAvian influenza, or bird flu, is a highly contagious viral disease that primarily affects birds. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the disease has also been found in other animals, such as pigs and dogs in China, Indonesia, and Vietnam, as well as domestic cats in Germany.\n\nIt spreads easily among birds through nasal and eye secretions, as well as manure, and it can prove deadly in domestic poultry.\n\nWhile it is unclear how the Mexico resident became infected, multiple cases of avian influenza have been reported in the country in recent months, including one outbreak detected in a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoac\u00e1n in March.\n\nAnother outbreak was identified in March in poultry in Texcoco, in the State of Mexico, and another in April in the municipality of Temascalapa in the same state, the health body said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" the WHO said Wednesday.\n\nThe latest discovery marks the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico, according to the UN body.\n\nNo further cases of the virus were reported during an epidemiological investigation into the latest case. Seventeen people who were at the hospital where the man died were monitored, with health officials only reporting a runny nose in one of them between April 28-29.\n\nBird Flu Outbreak Reported Among American Farmers\n\nNone of those individuals tested positive for influenza or SARS-CoV 2, the healthy body noted.\n\nAdditionally, 12 other people were identified as having been \"near\" the man's home before his hospitalization and death, according to the WHO.\n\nSeven of those people were symptomatic and five asymptomatic, however, all of those individuals subsequently tested negative for SARS-CoV-2, influenza A, and influenza B.\n\nDespite the man's death, the UN agency said Wednesday that -- based on available information -- the current risk to the general population posed by this virus is low.\n\nThe WHO also said the case is unrelated to a different outbreak of bird flu, H5N1, that has been detected in the United States, although both are H5 avian viruses.\n\nThat outbreak has so far infected three individuals; all of whom were dairy farm workers.\n\nAlong with the United States and Mexico, Australia has also reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection this year, with health officials stating in May that there were no signs of transmission.\n\nHealth officials in the country have, however, found additional poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NTD"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avian_influenza", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "8163730772", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:03:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:03:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T00:03:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/avian-h5-flu-virus-mexico/", "title": "WHO confirms first fatal human case of avian H5 flu strain in Mexico", "body": "A man died in Mexico City earlier this year after becoming ill with a strain of avian flu virus that had never previously been confirmed in humans anywhere in the world, the World Health Organization (WHO) said Wednesday.\n\nThe WHO said in a statement that Mexican authorities reported \"a confirmed fatal case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N2) virus\" on May 23.\n\nThe infection was detected in a M\u00e9xico state resident who was hospitalized in Mexico City, the WHO said.\n\n\"This is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico,\" the agency said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" it added.\n\nThe WHO said that it had assessed the current risk to the general population from the virus as \"low.\"\n\nThe source of the virus in this fatality case has yet to be determined, but avian influenza outbreaks often occur in poultry farms. (Cuartoscuro)The man who died was 59 years old and had \"multiple underlying medical conditions,\" the WHO said.\n\nHe \"had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals,\" the WHO said, and \"had already been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms,\" according to the case's relatives.\n\n\"On 17 April, the case developed fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general malaise. On 24 April, the case sought medical attention, was hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases ... and died the same day due to complications of his condition,\" the WHO said.\n\nIt said that no further cases of the same bird flu strain were detected during an epidemiological investigation.\n\n\"Of the 17 contacts identified and monitored at the hospital where the case died, one reported a runny nose between 28 and 29 April,\" the WHO said.\n\nThe agency noted that a \"high pathogenicity avian influenza A(H5N2) outbreak was detected in a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoac\u00e1n,\" which borders M\u00e9xico state, in March.\n\nIt also noted that two \"low pathogenicity\" A(H5N2) bird flu outbreaks occurred this year in M\u00e9xico state, one in Texcoco in March and another in Temascalapa in April.\n\n\"Thus far, it has not been possible to establish if this human case is related to the recent poultry outbreaks,\" the WHO said.\n\nUnited States media noted that the avian flu strain that caused the fatality in Mexico is different from the one currently circulating in cattle in the U.S. that has infected three dairy workers there. That strain is H5N1.\n\nThe WHO noted in its statement that \"sporadic human cases\" of infection with avian influenza viruses \"are not unexpected.\"\n\nThe risk comes from \"exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments,\" the agency said, explaining that \"the current likelihood of sustained human-to-human spread is low.\"\n\nThe WHO also noted that \"there are no specific vaccines for preventing influenza A(H5) virus infection in humans\" but \"candidate vaccines to prevent A(H5) infection in humans have been developed for pandemic preparedness purposes.\"", "source": {"uri": "8163767003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:50:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:50:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T00:48:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jun/06/mexico-man-dies-from-first-human-case-of-bird-flu-strain-h5n2", "title": "Mexico man dies from first human case of bird flu strain H5N2", "body": "Scientists are on alert for signs the virus is adapting to spread more easily among humans, after the WHO announced the death from April\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) has said a man's death in Mexico was caused by a strain of bird flu called H5N2 that has never before been found in a human.\n\nThe WHO said Wednesday it wasn't clear how the person became infected. \"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal that bird flu is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nBut the UN agency said Wednesday said the current risk of the bird flu virus to the general population in Mexico is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old man, who had been hospitalised in Mexico City, died on 24 April after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general discomfort, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry added in a statement on Wednesday that there had so far been no evidence of person-to-person transmission of bird flu in the case of the man who died, and that he had several prior health conditions. All people who had contact with him have tested negative, it said.\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state, but said at the time it did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March, but authorities haven't been able to find a connection.\n\nScientists said the case in Mexico is unrelated to the outbreak of a different strain of bird flu - H5N1 - in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nAndrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" he said.\n\nCases of bird flu have now been identified in mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in the state of Victoria.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-06-380212259", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:58:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:58:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:55:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/person-in-mexico-died-of-a-bird-flu-strain-that-hadnt-been-confirmed-9374982/", "title": "Person in Mexico died of a bird flu strain that hadn't been confirmed before in a human | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "According to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17.\n\nA death in Mexico was caused by a strain of bird flu called H5N2 that has never before been found in a human, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.\n\nThe WHO said it wasn't clear how the person became infected, although H5N2 has been reported in poultry in Mexico. There are numerous types of bird flu. H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the US That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Hospital care was sought on April 24 and the person died the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.The WHO said the risk to people in Mexico is low, and that no further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March but authorities haven't been able to find a connection.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu {"uri": "2024-06-380823573", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:04:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:04:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:04:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://tittlepress.com/health/3150297/", "title": "WHO confirms 1st human death of bird flu strain H5N2", "body": "MEXICO CITY - The first confirmed human case of a strain of bird flu called H5N2 has died, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nThe 59-year-old man lived in Mexico. The WHO said it wasn't clear how he became infected, although H5N2 has been reported in poultry in the country.\n\nBefore this case, H5N2 had never before been found in a human, officials said.\n\nH5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\n1st human death from bird flu strain H5N2\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a man who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17, according to the WHO release.\n\nMexico's public health department said in a statement that he had underlying ailments, including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHospital care was sought on April 24 and the man died the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to people in Mexico is low, and that no further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March but authorities haven't been able to find a connection.\n\nMexican officials also are monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu viruses.\n\nBird flu symptoms in humans\n\nAlthough bird flu viruses usually do not infect people, there have been some rare cases of human infection, the CDC says on its website.These cases have ranged in severity from no symptoms or mild illness to severe disease that resulted in death, the agency notes.\n\nSymptoms of bird flu virus in humans can include no symptoms or mild illness, such as eye redness, or mild flu-like upper respiratory symptoms. But symptoms can also be severe, including pneumonia requiring hospitalization, fever, cough, sore throat, runny nose, muscle or body aches, headaches, fatigue, and shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, the CDC says.\n\nLess common signs and symptoms include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, or seizures.", "source": {"uri": "tittlepress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "tittlepress.com"}, H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Hospital care was sought on April 24 and the person died the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to people in Mexico is low, and that no further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March but authorities haven't been able to find a connection.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu viruses.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. {"uri": "8164857421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:22:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:22:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:22:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://news24online.com/lifestyle/first-human-bird-flu-death-assessing-the-risk-of-human-to-human-transmission/280922/", "title": "Human Bird Flu: Is Human-to-Human Transmission Possible?", "body": "As of now, there is no evidence of human-to-human transmission of bird flu in the case of the man who died in Mexico, according to the nation's health ministry\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed on Wednesday the death of a 59-year-old man from bird flu. This first human fatality from bird flu raises a critical question: Can the virus be transmitted from one infected person to another?\n\n\"On 23 May 2024, the Mexico IHR NFP reported to PAHO/WHO a confirmed case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N2) virus detected in a 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico who was hospitalized in Mexico City and had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals.The case had multiple underlying medical conditions. The case's relatives reported that the case had already been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms,\" WHO has said in a press release.\n\nAs of now, there is no evidence of human-to-human transmission of bird flu in the case of the man who died in Mexico, according to the nation's health ministry. The man had multiple pre-existing health conditions, and all individuals who had contact with him tested negative for the virus, the ministry stated.\n\nAccording to the WHO, 17 people who had contact with the deceased were identified and monitored in the hospital. Among them, one person reported a runny nose between April 28 and 29. However, samples taken from these hospital contacts between May 27 and 29 tested negative for both influenza and SARS-CoV-2. Additionally, 12 more contacts (seven symptomatic and five asymptomatic) near the man's residence also tested negative for the flu.\n\nThe Mexican health ministry has confirmed that the detected bird flu does not pose a risk to the general population. The source of the infection in this case remains unidentified.\n\nIn March 2024, a highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N2) outbreak was detected at a backyard poultry farm in Michoac\u00e1n, a state bordering the State of Mexico where the deceased man lived, according to the WHO.\n\nH5N2 is a subtype of the avian influenza virus, primarily affecting birds, including domestic poultry and wild waterfowl. It is highly pathogenic, causing severe illness and high mortality rates in bird populations. Although H5N2 poses a significant threat to the poultry industry, leading to substantial economic losses, it has a low risk of transmission to humans. Effective biosecurity measures and surveillance are crucial for managing H5N2 outbreaks.", "source": {"uri": "news24online.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News24"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-380222888", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:21:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:21:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:41:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13499789/Person-Mexico-died-bird-flu-strain-hadnt-confirmed-human-WHO-says.html", "title": "Man in Mexico died of a bird flu strain that hadn't been confirmed...", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - A man's death in Mexico was caused by a strain of bird flu called H5N2 that has never before been found in a human, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.\n\nThe WHO said it wasn\u00b4t clear how the man became infected, although H5N2 has been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\nThere are numerous types of bird flu. H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old man who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Mexico's public health department said in a statement that he had underlying ailments, including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nFILE - The logo of the World Health Organization is seen at the WHO headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland, June 11, 2019. A death in Mexico was caused by a strain of bird flu that has never before been found in a human, the World Health Organization said Wednesday. (AP Photo/Anja Niedringhaus, File)\n\nHospital care was sought on April 24 and the man died the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to people in Mexico is low, and that no further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March but authorities haven\u00b4t been able to find a connection. Mexican officials also are monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu viruses.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute\u00b4s Science and Educational Media Group. variant of bird flu.\n\nThe patient, who died on April 24 after developing fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea and nausea, had \"no history of exposure to poultry or other animals\" and \"multiple underlying medical conditions\", the WHO said.\n\nMexican health authorities reported the confirmed case of human infection with the virus to the UN health body on May 23, after a 59-year-old was taken to hospital in Mexico City.\n\nThe WHO said the case was the \"first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally\".\n\nThe source of exposure {"uri": "2024-06-380238294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "00:55:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T00:55:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:55:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/health/2024/06/05/bird-flu-mexico-death-world-health-organization/73991349007/", "title": "Patient in Mexico dies after bird flu infection, becoming strain's first human fatality: WHO", "body": "The 59-year-old died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort a week prior, according to WHO. The victim, who officials did not identify, had multiple underlying medical issues before presenting acute symptoms.\n\nThe patient was bedridden in Mexico City for three weeks and later died due to complications from the infection.\n\nLab results confirmed it was first human death of someone infected with the avian influenza subtype A(H5N2) and the first human H5 virus infection reported in Mexico, per WHO.\n\nThe individual had no prior exposure to poultry or other animals and the victim's source of exposure to the virus is unknown, WHO said.\n\nIn Mexico, cases of the A(H5N2) strain of bird flu have been detected in poultry.\n\nAt least three bird flu cases in humans the U.S. have been linked to work on dairy farms, but those are a different subtype of the virus (H5N1), health officials have said.\n\nRisk to general population is low\n\nThe H5N2 strain differs from the other avian influenza cases that have caused a multi-state outbreak in cattle, since late last year.\n\nWHO officials clarified that the current risk to the general population is low based on available information.\n\n\"This case does not change the current WHO recommendations on public health measures and surveillance of influenza,\" the organization wrote.\n\nScientists will conduct an epidemiologic investigation in any case of a \"confirmed or suspected human infection caused by a novel influenza A virus with pandemic potential\" including the bird flu, according to the WHO. Those experts will also analyze unusual events that could signal person-to-person transmission of the virus and collect clinical samples, the agency said.\n\nWhat is bird flu?\n\nBird flu, or avian flu, is a contagious infection that spreads among wild birds and can infect domestic poultry and other animal species. The virus does not often spread to humans but sporadic infections have been reported. There are several strains all belonging to influenza A-type viruses.\n\nThe most common subtypes that may affect humans are A (H5N1), A (H7N9) and A (H9N2), according to the Cleveland Clinic.\n\nIn humans, symptoms can resemble a typical flu but may advance into more serious respiratory symptoms.\n\nIn birds, avian flu is highly contagious and cases can range in severity from mild to highly deadly. Infected birds shed the viruses in their saliva, nasal secretions and feces, meaning other birds can contract the virus through contact with those fluids directly or via contact with a contaminated {"uri": "8164074552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "06:15:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T06:15:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T06:12:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://newmail-ng.com/bird-flu/", "title": "WHO confirms first fatal case of human H5N2 bird flu in Mexico", "body": "The World Health Organisation (WHO) says Mexico has reported the first-ever laboratory-confirmed human case of the H5N2 avian influenza (bird flu).\n\nBird flu is a condition caused by an influenza virus that is generally observed among wild aquatic birds.\n\nIt can also infect domestic poultry, other birds, and animals. Bird flu infections in humans, though possible, are rare.\n\nThere are many strains of bird flu, one of which is the H5N2 strain.\n\nIn a statement on Wednesday, the WHO said the Mexico International Health Regulations (IHR) national focal point (NFP) reported the case on May 23.\n\nThe WHO said the human case was a 59-year-old resident who had developed a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea, and general discomfort.\n\nThe global health agency added that the victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, H5N2 viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\n\"The case's relatives reported that the case had already been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms. On April 17, the case developed fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general malaise.\n\n\"On April 24, the case sought medical attention, was hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases, 'Ismael Cosio Villegas' (INER per its acronym in Spanish) and died the same day due to complications of his condition,\" the statement reads.\n\nThe WHO said this is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of the H5N2 virus reported globally.\n\n\"No further cases were reported during the epidemiological investigation. Of the 17 contacts identified and monitored at the hospital where the case died, one reported a runny nose between April 28 and 29,\" the organisation said.\n\nIn March 2024, a H5N2 outbreak was detected in a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoac\u00e1n, which borders the state of Mexico where the case was residing.\n\nAlso in the same month, an outbreak of H5N2 was identified in poultry in Texcoco, a Mexican state, and a second outbreak of H5N2 in April in Temascalapa, in the same state.", "source": {"uri": "newmail-ng.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "New Mail Nigeria"}, {"uri": "8163814630", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "01:52:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T01:52:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T01:50:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/6/6/man-who-contracted-h5n2-bird-flu-dies-in-mexico-who-says", "title": "Man who contracted H5N2 bird flu dies in Mexico, WHO says", "body": "The H5N2 strain has never before been found in a human, health agency says, but stresses risk remains low.\n\nA man in Mexico with prior health complications has died after contracting the A(H5N2) strain of bird flu, the World Health Organization (WHO) has announced, cautioning that the risk to the general public by the virus remained low.\n\nThe global health agency, in a statement on Wednesday, said the 59-year-old died in Mexico City in April after developing symptoms including a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea and nausea.\n\nThe man's relatives said he had already been bedridden for three weeks for other reasons before the onset of his acute symptoms.\n\nMexico's public health department said in a statement that the man's underlying ailments included chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHe sought hospital care on April 24 and died on the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was A(H5N2), the WHO said.\n\nIt was the \"first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally\", the agency added.\n\nAndrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University in the United States, told the Reuters news agency that the man's prior health conditions put him at \"a risk of more severe influenza\".\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark\".\n\nThe WHO said the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, although cases of A(H5N2) have been reported in poultry in Mexico. These include in a backyard chicken farm in Michoacan state, which borders Mexico State, where the man lived, but authorities have so far been unable to establish a connection.\n\nThe WHO said no further human cases have been discovered despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in hospital.\n\n\"Based on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low,\" it said.\n\nMexico's Ministry of Health also said there was \"no risk of contagion for the population,\" noting that \"all samples from identified contacts [of the patient] have been negative\".\n\nAuthorities are monitoring farms near the victim's home and have established a permanent monitoring system to detect other cases in wildlife in the area, the ministry added.\n\nA different variant of bird flu, A(H5N1), has been spreading for weeks among dairy cow herds in the US, with a small number of cases reported among humans.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of A(H5N6) in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" Pekosz said.", "source": {"uri": "aljazeera.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Al Jazeera Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": WHO", "body": "GENEVA, Switzerland - The World Health Organization said Wednesday a person in Mexico had died in the first confirmed human case globally of infection with the H5N2 variant of bird flu.\n\nThe patient, who died on April 24 after developing fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea and nausea, had \"no history of exposure to poultry or other animals\" and \"multiple underlying medical conditions\", the WHO said.\n\nMexican health authorities reported the confirmed case of human infection with the virus to the UN health body on May 23, after a 59-year-old was taken to hospital in Mexico City.\n\nThe WHO said the case was the \"first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally\".\n\nThe source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the WHO said, although cases of H5N2 have been reported in poultry in the country.\n\nAccording to the UN health body, H5N2 cases affected poultry in the state of Michoacan in March, with other outbreaks identified in the State of Mexico.\n\nBut it said establishing a link between the human case and the poultry infections was so far impossible, estimating the risk to people as \"low\".\n\nA different variant of bird flu, H5N1, has been spreading for weeks among dairy cow herds in the United States, with a small number of cases reported among humans.\n\nBut none of the cases are human-to-human infections, with the disease instead jumping from cattle to people, authorities have said.", "source": {"uri": "newsinfo.inquirer.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Inquirer.net"}, {"uri": "8164466477", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "10:27:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T10:27:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T10:26:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/06/06/know-new-deadly-bird-flu-strain-20983041/", "title": "What do we know about new deadly bird flu strain?", "body": "The first human victim of a deadly new strain of bird flu known as H5N2 was announced dead this week by the World Health Organisation.\n\nA 59-year-old man in Mexico City was admitted to hospital on April 17 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, nausea and diarrhoea and died a week later, the organisation reported.\n\nThe victim had no previous exposure to poultry or animals, and his death is both the first time a human has been killed by the deadly new H5N2 strain- and the first time the disease has been spotted in Mexico.\n\nHere's everything we know about the disease so far:\n\nThere are numerous types of bird flu. H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nBefore the H5N2 case was confirmed, it was unclear whether it could infect humans.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the U.S. Centres for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March, but authorities were unable to find a connection. Mexican officials also are monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu viruses.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old man who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhoea on April 17.\n\nMexico's public health department said in a statement that he had underlying ailments, including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHospital care was sought on April 24 and the man died the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to people in Mexico is low, and that no further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital.\n\nThe WHO say they have not changed their public health advice following news of the outbreak, and encourage people to take the same precautions as normal to avoid influenza.\n\nIn a statement, the organisation said: 'Based on the available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus to be low.\n\n'If needed, the risk assessment will be reviewed should further epidemiological or virological information, including information on A(H5N2) viruses detected in local animal populations, become available.'\n\nElsewhere in their assessment, the organisation urged local health services to be vigilant of any potential outbreaks and to report them to the WHO at the earliest opportunity.\n\nTravellers to countries with known outbreaks of animal influenza such as Mexico should avoid farms, contact with animals in live animal markets, entering areas where animals may be slaughtered, or contact with any surfaces that may have been contaminated with animal faeces, WHO reports.\n\nAnyone travelling to Mexico should also wash their hands often with soap and water, they added.\n\nIn their report, WHO advised: 'Travellers should follow good food safety and good food hygiene practices.\n\n'Should infected individuals from affected areas travel internationally, their infection may be detected in another country during travel or after arrival. If this occurs, further community-level spread is considered unlikely as this virus has not acquired the ability to transmit easily among humans.\n\n'WHO does not advise special traveller screening at points of entry or restrictions regarding the current situation of influenza viruses at the human-animal interface.'\n\nAccording to the NHS, the main symptoms of bird flu can appear very quickly and include:\n\nOther early symptoms may include: diarrhoea, sickness, stomach pain, chest pain, bleeding from the nose and gums and conjunctivitis.\n\nIt usually takes 3 to 5 days for the first symptoms to appear after you've been infected.\n\nWithin days of symptoms appearing, it's possible to develop more severe complications such as pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.\n\nThere is currently no vaccine for bird flu, the NHS added, although the WHO is reportedly working on one in the event of a pandemic-level threat.", "source": {"uri": "metro.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Metro"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tom_sanders@metro.co.uk", "name": "Tom Sanders", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avian_influenza", "type": {"uri": "8163721377", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "23:52:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T23:52:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T23:50:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.investing.com/news/world-news/person-with-bird-flu-died-in-mexico-who-says-3472827", "title": "Person with bird flu died in Mexico, WHO says By Reuters", "body": "(Reuters) -A person with prior health complications who had contracted bird flu died in Mexico in April and the source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday.\n\nWHO said the current risk of bird flu virus to the general population is low.\n\nThe 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico had been hospitalized in Mexico City and died on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general discomfort, WHO said.\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nIt was the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus globally and the first avian H5 virus reported in a person in Mexico, according to the WHO.\n\nScientists said the case is unrelated to the outbreak of H5N1 bird flu in the United States that has so far infected three dairy farm workers.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry also said in a statement the source of infection had not been identified.\n\nThe victim had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals but had multiple underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms, the WHO said.\n\nMexico's health ministry said the person had chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.\n\n\"That immediately puts a person at risk of more severe influenza, even with seasonal flu,\" said Andrew Pekosz, an influenza expert at Johns Hopkins University.\n\nBut how this individual got infected \"is a big question mark that at least this initial report doesn't really address thoroughly.\"\n\nIn March, Mexico's government reported an outbreak of A(H5N2) in an isolated family unit in the country's western Michoacan state. The government said the cases did not represent a risk to distant commercial farms, nor to human health.\n\nAfter the April death, Mexican authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, the agency said.\n\nMexico's Health Ministry said there was no evidence of person-to-person transmission in the case and farms near the victim's home were monitored.\n\nOther people in contact with the person tested negative for bird flu, the health ministry and the WHO said.\n\nBird flu has infected mammals such as seals, raccoons, bears and cattle, primarily due to contact with infected birds.\n\nScientists are on alert for changes in the virus that could signal it is adapting to spread more easily among humans.\n\nThe United States has reported three cases of H5N1 human infection after exposure to cows since an outbreak was detected in dairy cattle in March. Two had symptoms of conjunctivitis, while the third also had respiratory symptoms.\n\nAlthough the death in Mexico was not the same strain as the one that is currently infecting cattle in the United States, they are both H5 avian viruses.\n\nPekosz said that since 1997, H5 viruses have continuously shown a propensity to infect mammals more than any other avian influenza virus.\n\n\"So it continues to ring that warning bell that we should be very vigilant about monitoring for these infections, because every spillover is an opportunity for that virus to try to accumulate those mutations that make it better infect humans,\" Pekosz said.\n\nAustralia reported its first human case of A(H5N1) infection in May, noting there were no signs of transmission. It has however found more poultry cases of H7 bird flu on farms in Victoria state.", "source": {"uri": "investing.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Investing.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-06-380524248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:49:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:49:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:13:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/who-confirms-first-ever-human-death-from-new-bird-flu-strain-in-mexico", "title": "WHO Confirms First-Ever Human Death from New Bird Flu Strain in Mexico", "body": "Washington: A 59-year-old man in Mexico died from a strain of bird flu called H5N2, which has never before been identified in a human, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced Wednesday. The source of the man's infection remains unclear, although H5N2 has been detected in poultry in Mexico.\n\nH5N2 differs from H5N1, the strain that has affected multiple dairy cow herds in the US, resulting in mild infections in three farmworkers. Various bird flu strains have previously caused human fatalities worldwide, including 18 deaths in China from H5N6 during a 2021 outbreak, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials informed the WHO that the deceased man, who had no known exposure to poultry or other animals, passed away in a Mexico City hospital. The man, bedridden due to unrelated health issues, developed a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhoea on April 17. He sought hospital care on April 24 and died the same day. Initial tests indicated an unidentified flu type, which was later confirmed as H5N2 after several weeks of lab testing.\n\nThe WHO stated that the risk to the public in Mexico is low, with no further human cases detected among those who had contact with the deceased. Three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 were reported in nearby regions of Mexico in March, but no direct link to the man's infection has been established. Authorities are also monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk of human infection for those in close contact with the flocks. Health authorities are vigilant for signs of the virus evolving to spread more easily among humans, particularly as more mammal species are being affected by bird flu viruses.", "source": {"uri": ExBulletin", "body": "The 59-year-old man lives in Mexico, where the H5N2 virus has been reported in poultry, but the WHO said it was unclear how it was transmitted.\n\nOfficials said the H5N2 virus had never been found in humans before this incident.\n\nH5N2 is not the same as the strain that infected Multiple dairy herds in the United States The strain, called H5N1, caused mild infection in three farm workers.\n\nOther types of bird flu have caused deaths around the world in the past, including the H5N6 outbreak in China in 2021, which killed 18 people, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials have alerted the WHO that a man who died in a Mexico City hospital had been infected with the virus despite having no known contact with poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to the WHO statement, the patient's family said he had been bedridden for unrelated reasons until April 17, when he began showing symptoms of fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea.\n\nMexico's public health agency said in a statement that he had underlying conditions including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHe was treated at a hospital on April 24 but died the same day.\n\nInitial tests detected an unknown type of influenza, but laboratory tests over the next few weeks confirmed it was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to the Mexican population was low and that no new cases had been found so far, despite testing people who had come into contact with the dead at home and in hospital.\n\nIn March, there were three outbreaks of H5N2 avian influenza in poultry near Mexico, but authorities have not been able to determine a link.\n\nMexican authorities are also monitoring the birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nIf avian flu spreads among poultry, people in close contact with the flocks are at risk of infection. Health officials are closely watching for signs that the virus is evolving to spread more easily from person to person, and experts are concerned that more mammal species are infected with the avian flu virus.\n\nAvian influenza viruses do not normally infect humans, but there have been rare cases of human infection. The CDC states on its website:The severity of these cases ranges from asymptomatic or mild illness to severe illness leading to death, the agency said.\n\nWhen avian influenza viruses infect humans, they can be asymptomatic or cause mild illness such as red eyes or mild flu-like upper respiratory symptoms, but can also cause severe symptoms such as pneumonia requiring hospitalization, fever, cough, sore throat, runny nose, muscle or body aches, headache, fatigue, and shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, according to the CDC.\n\nLess common signs and symptoms include diarrhea, {"uri": "8164605657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:50:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:50:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:49:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/man-in-mexico-died-of-a-bird-flu-strain-that-hadnt-been-confirmed-before-in-a-human-who-says/", "title": "Man in Mexico died of a bird flu strain that hadn't been confirmed before in a human, WHO says - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- A man's death in Mexico was caused by a strain of bird flu called H5N2 that has never before been found in a human, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.\n\nThe WHO said it wasn't clear how the man became infected, although H5N2 has been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\nThere are numerous types of bird flu. H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old man who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Mexico's public health department said in a statement that he had underlying ailments, including chronic kidney failure, diabetes and high blood pressure.\n\nHospital care was sought on April 24 and the man died the same day.\n\nInitial tests showed an unidentified type of flu that subsequent weeks of lab testing confirmed was H5N2.\n\nThe WHO said the risk to people in Mexico is low, and that no further human cases have been discovered so far despite testing people who came in contact with the deceased at home and in the hospital.\n\nThere had been three poultry outbreaks of H5N2 in nearby parts of Mexico in March but authorities haven't been able to find a connection. Mexican officials also are monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected. Health authorities are closely watching for any signs that the viruses are evolving to spread easily from person to person, and experts are concerned as more mammal species contract bird flu viruses.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-06-380096986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:32:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:32:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:32:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.who.int/emergencies/disease-outbreak-news/item/2024-DON520", "title": "Human infection caused by avian Influenza A(H5N2)- Mexico", "body": "On 23 May 2024, the Mexico International Health Regulations (IHR) National Focal Point (NFP) reported to PAHO/WHO a confirmed fatal case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N2) virus detected in a resident of the State of Mexico who was hospitalized in Mexico City. This is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and the first avian H5 virus infection in a person reported in Mexico. Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico. According to the IHR (2005), a human infection caused by a novel influenza A virus subtype is an event that has the potential for high public health impact and must be notified to the WHO. Based on available information, WHO assesses the current risk to the general population posed by this virus as low.\n\nOn 23 May 2024, the Mexico IHR NFP reported to PAHO/WHO a confirmed case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N2) virus detected in a 59-year-old resident of the State of Mexico who was hospitalized in Mexico City and had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals. The case had multiple underlying medical conditions. The case's relatives reported that the case had already been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms.\n\nOn 17 April, the case developed fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general malaise. On 24 April, the case sought medical attention, was hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases \"Ismael Cosio Villegas\" (INER per its acronym in Spanish) and died the same day due to complications of his condition.\n\nResults from Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) of a respiratory sample collected and tested at INER on 24 April indicated a non-subtypeable influenza A virus. On 8 May, the sample was sent for sequencing to the Laboratory of Molecular Biology of Emerging Diseases Center for Research in Infectious Diseases (CIENI per its acronym in Spanish) of INER, which indicated that the sample was positive for influenza A(H5N2). On 20 May, the sample was received at the Institute of Epidemiological Diagnosis and Reference (InDRE per its acronym in Spanish) of the Mexico National Influenza Centre, for analysis by RT-PCR, obtaining a positive result for influenza A. On 22 May, sequencing of the sample confirmed the influenza subtype was A(H5N2).\n\nNo further cases were reported during the epidemiological investigation. Of the 17 contacts identified and monitored at the hospital where the case died, one reported a runny nose between 28 and 29 April. Samples taken from these hospital contacts between 27 and 29 May tested negative for influenza and SARS-CoV 2. Twelve additional contacts (seven symptomatic and five asymptomatic) were identified near the case's residence. Samples of pharyngeal exudate, nasopharyngeal swabs and serum were obtained from these individuals. On 28 May, the InDRE reported that all twelve samples from contacts near the patient's residence tested negative for SARS-CoV-2, influenza A and influenza B, as determined by RT-PCR. The results of the serological samples are pending.\n\nIn March 2024, a high pathogenicity avian influenza A(H5N2) outbreak was detected in a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoac\u00e1n, which borders the State of Mexico where the case was residing\n\nAdditionally, in March 2024, an outbreak of low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) A(H5N2) was identified in poultry in Texcoco, State of Mexico, and a second outbreak of LPAI A(H5N2) in April in the municipality of Temascalapa in the same state. Thus far, it has not been possible to establish if this human case is related to the recent poultry outbreaks (1).\n\nA study describing the continuous circulation of low pathogenicity avian influenza H5N2 viruses in Mexico and spread to several other countries was published in 2022 (2).", "source": {"uri": "who.int", "dataType": "news", "title": "who.int"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164249707", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "08:15:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T08:15:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T08:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://english.jagran.com/world/who-confirms-worlds-first-bird-flu-death-in-mexico-know-symptoms-of-highly-potent-avian-influenza-in-humans-10165385", "title": "WHO Confirms World's First Bird Flu Death In Mexico; Know Symptoms Of Highly Potent Avian Influenza In Humans", "body": "The World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed the first human death from bird flu following a worrying rise in cases. The victim, a 59-year-old man from Mexico, succumbed to avian influenza A (H5N2). The man died on April 24 after experiencing symptoms such as fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea, and general malaise, Mexican health authorities said. This is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of H5N2 globally and the first avian (bird) H5 virus infection reported in Mexico.\n\nThe victim reportedly had no prior contact with poultry or other animals, raising concerns about how the virus was contracted. He had been bedridden for three weeks before succumbing to severe symptoms of bird flu. It is believed that pre-existing conditions may have worsened his health, contributing to his death.\n\nThe specific strain and its impact on humans are still being investigated. The WHO was alerted about the case on May 23, prompting global health authorities to monitor the situation closely. \"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" WHO said in a statement.\n\nExperts note that the H5N2 strain responsible for this death is different from the H5N1 strain currently affecting livestock in the US. In March, H5N1 was detected in US dairy herds, with cases confirmed in three dairy workers. Surveillance and preventive measures are being intensified to control the spread of the virus.\n\nALSO READ: Sunita Williams, Indian-Origin Astronaut, Flies To Space Onboard Boeing Starliner", H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nOther bird flu varieties have killed people across the world in previous years, including 18 people in China during an outbreak of H5N6 in 2021, according to a timeline of bird flu outbreaks from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nMexican health officials alerted the WHO that a 59-year-old man who died in a Mexico City hospital had the virus despite no known exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nAccording to family members, the WHO release said, the patient had been bedridden for unrelated reasons before developing a fever, shortness of breath and diarrhea on April 17. Mexican officials also are monitoring birds near a shallow lake on the outskirts of Mexico City.\n\nWhenever bird flu circulates in poultry, there is a risk that people in close contact with flocks can become infected.
