{"uri": "8164768809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:29:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:29:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:28:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://endtimeheadlines.org/2024/06/update-new-strain-of-bird-flu-never-seen-before-in-humans-has-killed-a-man-in-mexico/", "title": "UPDATE: New strain of bird flu never seen before in humans has killed a man in Mexico", "body": "A new strain of bird flu never seen before in humans has killed a man in Mexico.\n\nThe WHO stated that the patient had been hospitalized in Mexico City with a strain of bird flu known as H5N2. The strain has largely gone under the radar, and the outbreak has raised questions about how much damage it could cause.\n\nIn a report about the situation, the WHO explained that they were notified of a human infection on May 23. It was related to a 59-year-old resident of Mexico who had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals. He also had several other underlying medical conditions.\n\nHe had already been bedridden for three weeks prior to the onset of acute symptoms of avian flu. On April 17, he started experiencing \"fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general malaise\". On April 24, he died due to complications from the condition.\n\nThe WHO said that it carried out an epidemiological investigation into the 17 people who came into close contact with the deceased. Only one of them reported having a runny nose.\n\nIt comes shortly after Australia marked its first recorded human case of a virulent strain of bird flu in a child who fell sick after returning from overseas.\n\nThe child contracted the H5N1 strain of the disease, which has been spreading globally and causing widespread deaths among birds, upon returning to the Australian state of Victoria.\n\nThe youngster reportedly suffered a \"severe infection\" after returning from India in March, but has since made a full recovery, Victoria's chief health officer confirmed on Wednesday.\n\n\"This is the first human case of H5N1 avian influenza in Australia,\" Dr Clare Looker said. \"The avian influenza virus was detected through further testing of positive influenza samples that takes place to detect novel or concerning flu virus strains, as part of Victoria's enhanced surveillance system.\n\n\"Contact tracing has not identified any further cases of avian influenza connected to this case,\" she added. Avian influenza does not easily spread between humans so the chances of additional cases in people was low, Dr Looker said.\n\nOn the same day, agricultural authorities revealed a different strain of bird flu had been detected in another part of Victoria at an egg farm. Authorities were alerted after a number of poultry deaths at the farm near Meredith, about 40km northwest of Geelong. Agriculture Victoria has ordered urgent testing after avian influenza was detected at the site.", "source": {"uri": "endtimeheadlines.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "End Time Headlines"}, {"uri": "8164181331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "07:30:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T07:30:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T07:30:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/health/who-confirms-1st-human-death-from-new-bird-flu-strain/3241631", "title": "WHO confirms 1st human death from new bird flu strain", "body": "The World Health Organization (WHO) announced Wednesday that a resident of Mexico became the world's first person to die from a bird flu strain not previously detected in humans.\n\nThe H5N2 strain of avian influenza has been recorded in birds worldwide, but no cases of human infection or deaths have been reported until now. The 59-year-old man, a resident of the State of Mexico in the central part of the country, had fallen ill in April.\n\nAccording to WHO, the man had numerous underlying medical conditions and had been bedridden for three weeks before developing acute symptoms. On April 17, he reported fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general malaise.\n\nOn April 24, he sought medical attention and was promptly hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases (INER), dying the same day.\n\nFollowing his death, health authorities at INER began testing samples collected from the deceased man. On May 8, the Laboratory of Molecular Biology of Emerging Diseases Center for Research in Infectious Diseases indicated that the sample was positive for influenza A(H5N2). By May 22, the Institute of Epidemiological Diagnosis and Reference confirmed the strain.\n\nSo far, health authorities do not know the origin of the contagion, since the man had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nThe epidemiological investigation followed 17 contacts identified and monitored at the hospital where the patient died and 12 additional contacts identified near the patient's residence, with all testing negative for SARS-Cov-2 and influenza. Although no further cases of avian flu have been reported, the results of all serological samples are pending.\n\nMultiple outbreaks of H5N2 have been reported in birds in Mexico, including an outbreak detected at a backyard poultry farm in the state of Michoacan, which borders the State of Mexico where the man was residing.\n\nAdditionally, two outbreaks of low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) A(H5N2) were reported in two municipalities in the State of Mexico. However, it has not been possible to establish if this human case is related to the recent poultry outbreaks.", "source": {"uri": "aa.com.tr", "dataType": "news", "title": "Anadolu Ajans\u0131"}, {"uri": "8164022068", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:30:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:30:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:29:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/2024/06/06/bird-flu-death-mexico-h5n2/", "title": "Man in Mexico dies in first known human case of H5N2 bird flu variant", "body": "The man, who suffered from other underlying health conditions, had no known exposure to poultry or other animals before being formally diagnosed by a laboratory with the H5N2 subtype of avian flu. The case marks the first time a human has been confirmed to be infected with this subtype, and the first time an avian H5 virus was confirmed in a person in Mexico.\n\n\"Due to the constantly evolving nature of influenza viruses, WHO continues to stress the importance of global surveillance,\" WHO said in a statement. \"This case does not change the current WHO recommendations on public health measures and surveillance of influenza,\" it added, rating current risks to the general population as \"low.\"\n\nThe man had been bedridden for three weeks for other reasons, before the onset of acute symptoms, according to WHO. His symptoms first appeared around April 17 and included fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea and general malaise.\n\nHe sought medical attention on April 24 and was hospitalized at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases in Mexico City. He died later that day.\n\nOther subtypes of H5 avian flu have spread to humans, but evidence from previous events have so far suggested that the viruses \"have not acquired the ability to sustain transmission between humans,\" WHO said. People who came in contact with the man shortly before his death have so far not tested positive for H5N2, it added.\n\nBird flu in general threatens the international poultry supply and comes with some risk of spreading to humans, typically through direct contact with an infected animal or contaminated environments. There are no known cases of an individual catching bird flu from eating properly cooked meat, according to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nA highly pathogenic form of bird flu was detected in a goat in March, the first confirmed case in the United States involving a domestic ruminant animal (i.e. cattle, sheep and goats). Within days, avian influenza was found in several U.S. cows and rapidly spread across state lines, with a dairy worker in Texas testing positive in April for H5N1, a different subtype than the one detected in the man in Mexico.\n\nExperts have criticized federal agencies in the United States for being slow to track and control the outbreak, with nine states observing outbreaks in cows as of Tuesday. Forty-eight states have recorded outbreaks in poultry, according to the CDC.\n\nFour human cases of avian flu have been reported in the United States since April 1; three of the infections followed exposure to dairy cows in Texas and Michigan, while one followed exposure to poultry in Colorado, the CDC said.\n\nFor those in places with known avian influenza outbreaks, WHO recommends avoiding contact with livestock as well as places where animals could have been raised, slaughtered or may have spread their feces. Basic hygiene such as frequent hand-washing is also recommended.", "source": {"uri": "washingtonpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Post"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164841964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:13:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:13:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.rt.com/news/598865-first-bird-flu-death/", "title": "First H5N2 bird flu death reported  --  RT World News", "body": "A man has died in Mexico with a new strain of avian flu never detected in humans before, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced Wednesday. Multiple strains of the virus are currently circulating in Europe and North America.\n\nThe 59-year-old male victim caught the H5N2 virus in April while he was already bedridden with \"multiple underlying medical conditions,\" the organization said in a statement. He quickly developed \"fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general malaise,\" passing away seven days after these symptoms showed.\n\nOther strains of avian flu - including H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8 - occasionally infect humans, with those who work in the poultry industry at particular risk. However, no human cases of H5N2 have ever been detected before.\n\nAccording to the WHO, there were three outbreaks of H5N2 at Mexican poultry farms in March and April. However, the agency noted that the deceased did not have any contact with any animals before he fell ill, and could not link the case with any of the recent outbreaks.\n\nTen US states have reported H5N1 infections since late March, with the virus infecting at least three people and spreading to cattle herds in nine states, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Since late last year, outbreaks have also been reported at poultry farms in Belgium, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, the UK, and several other countries.\n\nA total of 888 human cases of H5N1 have been reported worldwide since 2003, 463 of which have been fatal, according to WHO data.\n\nNo further human cases of H5N2 have been detected in Mexico, and the WHO stated that \"the current {"uri": "8165151491", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:54:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:54:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:50:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/latest-news-who-confirms-first-death-from-bird-flu-strain-h5n2-in-mexico-6019353.html", "title": "Latest News | WHO Confirms First Death from Bird Flu Strain H5N2 in Mexico | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Latest News at LatestLY. The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported the first confirmed death of a human infected with avian influenza A (H5N2), the virus causing bird flu.\n\nNew Delhi, Jun 6 (PTI) The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported the first confirmed death of a human infected with avian influenza A (H5N2), the virus causing bird flu.\n\nThis is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and infection in a person reported in Mexico, the WHO said in a statement.\n\nAlso Read | What Is the Oath of the Prime Minister of India? Who Administers the Oath of Office and Secrecy to PM?.\n\nThe infection was first reported to PAHO/WHO by the Mexico IHR NFP on May 23, 2024. A 59-year-old Mexico resident was hospitalised in Mexico City and had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals, it said.\n\nAccording to the statement, the individual had multiple underlying medical conditions and relatives reported the case to have been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms.\n\nAlso Read | ICAI CA Foundation Exam 2024: Admit Card for CA Foundation June Examination Released at eservices.icai.org, Know Steps To Download Hall Ticket.\n\nOn 17 April, the individual developed fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general malaise, according to the UN health agency's statement.\n\nHe sought medical attention on 24 April and was hospitalised at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases \"Ismael Cosio Villegas\" (INER) but died the same day due to complications of his condition, the statement said.\n\nThe same day, results from Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) of a respiratory sample collected and tested at INER indicated a non-subtypeable influenza A virus, it said.\n\nThe sample was on 8 May sent for sequencing to the Laboratory of Molecular Biology of Emerging Diseases Center for Research in Infectious Diseases (CIENI) of INER, which indicated that the sample was positive for influenza A(H5N2), the statement said.\n\nOn 20 May, the sample was received at the Institute of Epidemiological Diagnosis and Reference (InDRE) of the Mexico National Influenza Centre, for analysis by RT-PCR, obtaining a positive result for influenza A.\n\nTwo days later, on May 22, sequencing of the sample confirmed the influenza subtype was A(H5N2), the statement said.\n\nNo further cases were reported during the epidemiological investigation, the agency said.\n\nAffecting the upper respiratory tract, bird flu infections in humans can be mild to severe, sometimes fatal. Symptoms including conjunctivitis and gastrointestinal, have been reported, according to the WHO.\n\nThe viruses responsible for these infections normally spread in animals, but can also infect humans through direct contact with infected animals or contaminated environments, the statement said.", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, "authors": [], "concepts": The World Health Organization (WHO) has officially confirmed that the first fatal case of the A(H5N2) virus, a subtype of bird flu, occurred in Mexico.\n\nIn the statement made by WHO, it was reported that Mexican health authorities confirmed a case of infection with the A(H5N2) virus, which resulted in death. This case was recorded as the first A(H5N2) case confirmed by laboratory tests worldwide and seen in humans.\n\nWhile the source of the case has not yet been determined, it was reminded that the presence of the A(H5N2) virus in poultry in Mexico has been reported before. It is currently unknown how the virus is transmitted to humans. According to the International Health Regulations, the A(H5N2) virus, a new type, that causes infection in humans carries a high risk potential for public health. While the Mexico government reported an outbreak of A(H5N1) in the western state of Michoacan back in March, at the time it had said the strain didn't pose a risk to humans.\n\nAfter the death, however, Mexican health authorities confirmed the presence of the virus and reported the case to the WHO, according to the agency. especially in species of animals that have never had it before.\n\nIn April, a bird flu outbreak was confirmed in Kerala's Alappuzha after ducks in two districts tested positive for it.\n\nMeanwhile, Tamil Nadu has already set border checkposts for vigilance teams comprising veterinarians and support staff.\n\nAt such locations, vehicles transporting poultry products are being stopped and disinfection measures taken up or are turned back. So far, however, none of such proactive measures have been taken up by Telangana State, which has porous borders with multiple States, including Karnataka.\n\nAccording to the WHO, the most likely route of H5N2 infection to the deceased individual in Mexico could be through poultry. \"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, the H5N2 virus has been reported in poultry in Mexico. A human infection caused by a novel influenza A virus subtype has a potential for high public health impact,\" the WHO said.\n\nWhenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Human cases of infection with other H5 subtypes, including A(H5N1), A(H5N6) and A(H5N8) viruses, have been reported previously, the WHO made it clear.\n\nThe possibility of human infection, whenever the influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, should be a major reason enough for the Health Department to be proactive and focus on large-scale monitoring, surveillance and genetic testing.", {"uri": "8164764009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:25:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:25:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:25:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://hotair.com/jazz-shaw/2024/06/06/mexican-bird-flu-death-tells-us-something-about-fauci-n3789739", "title": "Mexican Bird Flu Death Tells Us Something About Fauci", "body": "There was some sad and potentially alarming news coming out of Mexico this week, where an unnamed 59-year-old man passed away in a hospital. After an investigation, doctors announced that the patient had died from a type of bird flu (H5N2) that had not previously been seen in humans. Unlike the more frequently discussed H5N1 strain that shows up in cows, H5N2 is most commonly seen in poultry populations. However, the patient in question did not work in the poultry industry and had no known connections to the birds according to his family. This news reached us during the same week that the sainted Anthony Fauci has been providing testimony about his involvement with the laboratory in Wuhan and the true origins of the COVID-19 virus. The two stories may be related in ways that are not immediately obvious to everyone. (Associated Press)\n\nA man's death in Mexico was caused by a strain of bird flu called H5N2 that has never before been found in a human, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.\n\nThe WHO said it wasn't clear how the man became infected, although H5N2 has been reported in poultry in Mexico.\n\nThere are numerous types of bird flu. H5N2 is not the same strain that has infected multiple dairy cow herds in the U.S. That strain is called H5N1 and three farmworkers have gotten mild infections.\n\nBefore anyone begins raising concerns about the possibility of a new, deadly pandemic, there are a few details about the death of the man in Mexico that are notable. Doctors are attributing his death to H5N2 and it appears that he had definitely contracted it. But it seems like a bit of a stretch to say that the bird flu killed him. The man had reportedly been bedridden for weeks and was in very poor health for quite a while. He was suffering from chronic kidney failure, diabetes, and high blood pressure. Had he been in more robust health typical of a man of his age, he might have shrugged off the bird flu as most people do when they contract any species of the flu. In his case, the bird flu may have simply pushed him over the edge.\n\nSo how does this story relate to Fauci and Wuhan? Before beginning, I will remind everyone that I am not a doctor and have had no formal training in this field, so take this with an appropriate grain of salt. But I cover this story frequently and have had to do a lot of research. I believe that the history of the bird flu should tell us something important about the origins of COVID and the gain of function research that was clearly taking place at the Wuhan Institute of Virology, funded by Fauci's office.\n\nFirst, consider the fact that doctors and researchers have known about the bird flu in its various forms for quite a while. H5N1 was first detected in the 90s and scientists have been tracking and monitoring it closely ever since. Its true origins will likely never be known beyond the belief that it first showed up in avian species as the name suggests. At some point, it made the jump from birds to cows, taking decades before it became a widespread problem. That process of migration is known as zoonotic spillover. It happens slowly because every virus evolves over time to use all of the available resources it finds in the host. Random mutations produce increasingly well-adapted variations that are more successful, reproduce more readily, and become more powerful and sometimes deadly as a result. But it takes time. In the decades that we've known about the H5N1 bird flu virus, it has infected just three dairy farm workers in the United States, none of whom died.\n\nBut that's not what happened with SARS-CoV-2. If patient zero had contracted COVID after eating a pangolin or a bat, the virus should have been struggling just to survive in its new human host. The person probably wouldn't have even become ill enough to bother seeing a doctor. Yet it wasn't. One person was infected in the vicinity of Wuhan followed by another and then dozens and hundreds more. In almost no time at all it was aboard planes headed for North America and the rest of the world. COVID came out of the gate locked and loaded and ready to run wild in the human body. People were dying, though it was thankfully only a relatively tiny percentage of patients with underlying conditions. How does that not speak to gain of function meddling?\n\nYet the government, at the direction of Dr. Fauci, did its level best to shut down any mention of the lab leak theory. Prominent virologists had their social media accounts shut down after studying the virus and saying that it demonstrated the hallmarks of being modified. Citizens who brought up the possibility were hounded and accused of being conspiracy theorists who were spreading misinformation. Pointing to evidence of the lab leak theory made you a racist with a hatred of the Chinese. To what purpose? Was it all just to prevent Anthony Fauci from having to admit what he'd been up to? Were they afraid of angering the Chinese by suggesting they had been messing around with potentially lethal, biological weapons of mass destruction? Were we afraid that people might find out that we've been working on the same type of things ourselves? I have the feeling that this story is far from over, and it's not going to end well for anyone. {"uri": "8164018513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "05:27:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T05:27:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T05:26:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/uk-news/man-59-first-world-die-29301882", "title": "Man, 59, is first in world to die from new strain of flu", "body": "Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info\n\nThe World Health Organisation says it has been informed of the first recorded human death from a new strain of flu. The patient had been hospitalised in Mexico City with a strain of bird flu known as H5N2, the WHO said in a statement.\n\nThe WHO said they were notified of a human infection on May 23. The disease was caught by a 59-year-old resident of Mexico who had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals and had several other underlying medical conditions.\n\nHe had already been bedridden for three weeks prior to the onset of acute symptoms of avian flu. On April 17, he started experiencing \"fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea and general malaise\". On April 24, he died due to complications from the condition.\n\nThe WHO said that it carried out an epidemiological investigation into the 17 people who came into close contact with the deceased. Only one of them reported having a runny nose.\n\nIt comes shortly after Australia marked its first recorded human case of a virulent strain of bird flu in a child who fell sick after returning from overseas. The child contracted the H5N1 strain of the disease, which has been spreading globally and causing widespread deaths among birds, upon returning to the Australian state of Victoria. The youngster reportedly suffered a \"severe infection\" after returning from India in March, but has since made a full recovery, Victoria's chief health officer confirmed on Wednesday.\n\n\"This is the first human case of H5N1 avian influenza in Australia,\" Dr Clare Looker said. \"The avian influenza virus was detected through further testing of positive influenza samples that takes place to detect novel or concerning flu virus strains, as part of Victoria's enhanced surveillance system.\n\n\"Contact tracing has not identified any further cases of avian influenza connected to this case,\" she added. Avian influenza does not easily spread between humans so the chances of additional cases in people was low, Dr Looker said.\n\nOn the same day, agricultural authorities revealed a different strain of bird flu had been detected in another part of Victoria at an egg farm. Authorities were alerted after a number of poultry deaths at the farm near Meredith, about 40km northwest of Geelong. Agriculture Victoria has ordered urgent testing after avian influenza was detected at the site.\n\nThat outbreak likely involved the H7N7 strain, not the highly pathogenic H5N1 variant, Chief Veterinary Officer Graeme Cooke said. \"There is a type of virus which is causing great concern in the USA and other parts of the world and has behaved unusually in that it has infected dairy cattle and some other marine mammals,' Dr Cooke told the ABC's Country Hour.\n\n\"This is not the strain that we're dealing with. This is a strain that's occurred in Australia before. It's likely not new.\" H7N7 is the most common type of bird flu in Australia and a H7 strain was one of those in the last bird flu outbreak in the country in 2020 which affected a third of egg farms {"uri": "8164674086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:40:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:40:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:30:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/man-mexico-dies-first-human-122358674.html", "title": "Man in Mexico dies with first human case of H5N2 bird flu", "body": "A 59-year-old man in Mexico has died with a type of bird flu - H5N2 - never recorded in people before now.\n\nThere is no risk to the wider public, say authorities, and none of the man's close contacts have caught the virus.\n\nIt is unclear how he got it, although there have been cases in some poultry farms in Mexico.\n\nInfections like this can sometime pass from animals to humans.\n\nThe man had other underlying health issues that likely made him vulnerable.\n\nHe had been bedridden for weeks before getting sick with fever and shortness of breath from bird flu, according to officials.\n\nThere is no evidence that the virus could start spreading between people and cause an outbreak, they say.\n\nThe World Health Organization and other authorities monitor strains of flu, like this one, that could have the potential mutate and become a threat.\n\nThere are many types or strains of avian or bird flu.\n\nAs well as birds, some wild mammals - such as seals, otters, wild dogs and foxes - can catch them too.\n\nCases do occur in people from time to time and patients usually get better.\n\nOne type of bird flu, called H5N1, has been spreading for weeks among dairy cow herds in the US, with a small number of cases reported among humans.\n\nThe UK recently declared itself bird-flu-free after recording no new cases of H5N1, following outbreaks in poultry and other captive birds.\n\nResponding to the news from Mexico, Prof Ian Brown, Avian Virology Group Lead, Pirbright Institute, said: \"The prompt follow up in healthcare professionals and family members in contact with the infected patient provides reassurance at present this is an isolated case.\"\n\nDr Ed Hutchinson from the University of Glasgow said it looked likely that the man's infection was a spillover event - meaning he had probably caught it from an infected animal somehow.\n\n\"At the moment surveillance is taking place, including testing people who may have been exposed to the virus but fought off the infection to see if they show any signs of an immune response. {"uri": "8164403146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:50:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:50:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:49:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.sciencemediacentre.org/expert-reaction-to-man-in-mexico-dies-of-h5n2-bird-flu/", "title": "expert reaction to man in Mexico dies of H5N2 bird flu", "body": "you are here: science media centre > roundups for journalists > expert reaction to man in Mexico dies of H5N2 bird flu\n\nScientists react to news that a man in Mexico has died of H5N2 bird flu.\n\nProf Ian Brown, Lead of Avian Science Programme, Pirbright Institute, said:\n\n\"The H5N2 in Mexico belongs to a distinct family of H5 viruses known to have been circulating in local birds for some time and is therefore quite different from other H5s causing sporadic human cases. It is not without precedent that we see very occasional reports of the detection of influenza A viruses from birds in severe human cases when there are major underlying health issues. The role of this virus in the fatal outcome cannot be assumed to directly responsible without further investigation. The prompt follow up in healthcare professionals and family members in contact with the infected patient provides reassurance at present this is an isolated case.\"\n\nDr Ed Hutchinson, Senior Lecturer, MRC-University of Glasgow Centre for Virus Research (MRC CVR), said:\n\n\"At a time when many people's attention has been focused on H5N1 influenza in cattle in the USA, this case is a reminder that there are lots of other influenza viruses out there that also have the potential to infect humans. However, it is important to stress that at the moment this case was a sad but isolated incident. At the moment there is no suggestion that this particular influenza virus has spread any further in humans.\n\n\"Details of the case are still emerging, but at the moment we know that the virus was an H5N2 influenza virus, making it distinct from the H5N1 influenza viruses that are currently spreading in cattle in the USA and in birds worldwide. Influenza viruses can exchange genes with each other, but whether or not that's happened here will only become clear when viral sequence data are available. For now, we know that there have been recent outbreaks of H5N2 influenza viruses in poultry in Mexico, suggesting that this case may have been related to one of those.\n\n\"Exactly how the person became infected is not yet known, but although there was no record of contact with poultry this sounds like it was most likely a \"spillover\" infection, in which a virus that was adapted to one species of host manages to infect a member of another species (in this case a human), but is not able to transmit any further. It's probably significant that the person in question had multiple underlying health conditions, and had been very unwell for some time before showing signs of this infection. This is likely to have made it easier for a virus that normally grows in birds to infect them, and unfortunately it may also led to them experiencing severe disease when they became unwell. It's not yet clear if the virus had to undergo any particular changes to replicate in this person (something that would definitely be required if it was to spread further in humans). This should become clearer if the virus' genes can be sequenced and compared to other similar viruses.\n\n\"At the moment surveillance is taking place, including testing people who may have been exposed to the virus but fought off the infection to see if they show any signs of an immune response. If there are more human infections with this virus it would become of wider concern, but for now it is a very sad but isolated case.\"\n\nProfessor Ian Jones, Professor of Virology, University of Reading, said:\n\n\"It is impossible to generalise from a single case. However, as H5N2 is present in Mexico and the infected individual had underlying medical conditions, which may have contributed to the outcome, it would be reasonable to suppose this is a one-off case of zoonotic transfer with no potential to spread. This would be consistent with previous examples of occasional avian influenza infections in people. Unless or until there is evidence of strain adaptation or sustained transmission, the risk to the population is very low. The case should act to reinforce the importance of monitoring and eradicating outbreaks in poultry as soon as they occur.\"\n\nDr Ed Hutchinson: I have received honoraria for work in a steering group of the Centre for Open Science (Open Practices in Influenza Research; 2021-2022) and on an advisory board for Seqirus (2022). I have unpaid positions on the board of the European Scientific Working group on Influenza and other respiratory viruses (ESWI) and as a scientific adviser to PinPoint Medical.\n\nFor all other experts, no reply to our request for DOIs was received.", "source": {"uri": "sciencemediacentre.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Science Media Centre"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": WHO warns 'Be prepared for a new pandemic coming'", "body": "The World Health Organization (WHO) announced that a 59-year-old patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, and nausea, and died. This death is recorded as the first human death caused by the A(H5N2) variant.\n\nThe A(H5N2) variant has previously been mainly seen among birds and rarely transmitted to humans. {"uri": "8163949827", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "04:22:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T04:22:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T04:22:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.gloucestershirelive.co.uk/news/health/bird-flu-symptoms-signs-first-9326310", "title": "First person in world dies from bird flu strain as it spreads - signs to spot", "body": "A man has been killed by a new and spreading strain of bird flu previously undetected in humans, sparking concerns about its potential global impact.\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) released a statement confirming that the Mexican patient was treated in Mexico City for an H5N2 avian influenza infection. This particular strain has not been on the global health radar, prompting questions about the threat it may pose.\n\nAccording to a WHO report, they were alerted to the human infection on May 23. The case involved a 59-year-old man from Mexico with no known contact with poultry or wildlife and who suffered from several other health issues, the Mirror reports.\n\nBefore developing acute avian flu symptoms, he had been bedridden for three weeks. His symptoms, which began on April 17, included \"fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general malaise\". Complications from the illness led to his death on April 24.\n\nREAD MORE: Doctor says it's fine to eat chocolate with 'strange spores' as they 'aren't insect eggs'\n\nFollowing the man's death, the WHO conducted an epidemiological investigation of the 17 individuals who had close contact with him. Among them, only one person reported symptoms of a runny nose. This incident follows closely after Australia reported its first human case of a highly pathogenic bird flu strain in a child who became ill after travelling abroad.\n\nA child in Victoria, Australia, contracted the H5N1 strain of bird flu after returning from a trip to India in March. The youngster suffered a \"severe infection\" but has since fully recovered, according to Victoria's chief health officer.\n\n\"This is the first human case of H5N1 avian influenza in Australia,\" Dr Clare Looker announced. She explained that the virus was detected through additional testing of positive influenza samples, as part of Victoria's enhanced surveillance system.\n\nDr Looker also confirmed that no further cases of avian influenza have been identified in connection with this case. She reassured that avian influenza does not easily spread between humans, so the likelihood of more cases is low.\n\nIn related news, agricultural authorities reported a different strain of bird flu at an egg farm in another part of Victoria. The alarm was raised following several poultry deaths at the farm near Meredith, approximately 40km northwest of Geelong. Agriculture Victoria has ordered urgent testing after avian influenza was detected at the site.\n\nChief Veterinary Officer Graeme Cooke has clarified that the recent outbreak likely involved the H7N7 strain, not the highly pathogenic H5N1 variant. Speaking to ABC's Country Hour, he said: \"There is a type of virus which is causing great concern in the USA and other parts of the world and has behaved unusually in that it has infected dairy cattle and some other marine mammals,' Dr Cooke told the ABC's Country Hour. This is not the strain that we're dealing with. This is a strain that's occurred in Australia before. It's likely not new.\"\n\nThe H7N7 strain is the most common type of bird flu in Australia, and was one of the strains involved in the last bird flu outbreak in 2020, which affected a third of egg {"uri": "2024-06-380672711", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "09:58:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T09:58:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T09:50:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/conspiracy-theories-spread-man-dies-new-bird-flu-strain-1908855", "title": "Conspiracy theories spread as man dies from new bird flu strain", "body": "Social media platforms are awash with conspiracy theories following the death of a Mexican man from a new strain of bird flu.\n\nThe theories are largely based on the false belief that the U.S. government is concocting a new pandemic ahead of the November election, four years on from the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, as a means to control the population and presumably tip the result in President Joe Biden's favor.\n\nThe Context\n\nAccording to the World Health Organization (WHO), the 59-year-old man died in Mexico City on April 24 after developing a fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea, nausea, and general discomfort. They say his death was caused by a strain of bird flu never before found in humans - H5N2.\n\nMexican authorities reported an outbreak in the Latin American country's western Michoacan state in March. After it was found in an isolated family unit.\n\nSince then, three nearby outbreaks of H5N2 among poultry have been reported.\n\nWhat We Know\n\n\"Although the source of exposure to the virus in this case is currently unknown, A(H5N2) viruses have been reported in poultry in Mexico,\" the WHO said Wednesday.\n\nAccording to the WHO, such viruses normally circulate in animals but can also infect humans.\n\nTransmission to humans usually occur via direct contact with either infected animals or contaminated environments.\n\nHuman infections may result in mild to severe upper respiratory tract infections, conjunctivitis, gastrointestinal symptoms, encephalitis, and encephalopathy. Infections can sometimes be fatal.\n\nViews\n\nConspiracy theories began circulating on X shortly after the news broke from prominent right-wing accounts with large followings.\n\nCharlie Kirk, founder and CEO of conservative organization Turning Point USA, posted: \"Election flu season is officially upon us! Bring it.\"\n\nKirk's post included a screenshot of web search results for news about the Mexican man's death.\n\nConservative podcast host Joey Mannarino said: \"Let me explain something about the bird flu outbreak. I won't vaccinate for it. I won't mask for it. I won't social distance for it. I won't use a \"green pass\" for it. I won't do ANYTHING for it. Go f*** yourselves.\"\n\nToby Rogers, who has more than 60,000 X followers and says he has a Ph.D, posted: \"The dude who supposedly died of bird flu in Mexico had \"chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes\" and \"had no history of exposure to poultry.\" Oh, so basically they made up the bird flu part. Because of course they did.\"\n\n\"BIRD FLU? VACCINE? BS! OPEN YOUR EYES! DO NOT COMPLY,\" an X user called AJ Huber posted. Huber's bio says they are a conservative and MAGA supporter.\n\nJournalist Kyle Becker suggested on X that the WHO was \"baselessly fearmongering\" amid efforts to create a global pandemic treaty.\n\nThe International Treaty on Pandemic Prevention, Preparedness, and Response, is a proposed international agreement aimed at strengthening the world's ability to prevent and respond to future pandemics. Negotiations are underway but it is a long way off from being implemented.\n\nThere is no evidence supporting any of the conspiracy theories or rumors circulating online.\n\nBird flu was first discovered in the 1800s and is constantly evolving, like any strain of influenza. Human to human transmission is extremely rare, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nWhat's Next\n\nAt this time the WHO is not advising restrictions such as special traveler screening. They also said the risk to the general population is low and that local health authorities are working to strengthen surveillance activities in poultry and wild birds near the case's proximity.\n\nEarlier in 2024, several people in the U.S. were infected with a strain of bird flu, including two in Michigan and one in Texas.\n\nLast month, two chickens at a live animal market in San Francisco tested positive for bird flu, with traces of the virus being detected in the city's wastewater, according to San Francisco Chronicle reports.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", {"uri": "8165141940", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:45:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:45:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:42:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/national/who-confirms-first-death-from-bird-flu-strain-h5n2-in-mexico-4748629", "title": "WHO confirms first death from bird flu strain H5N2 in Mexico", "body": "New Delhi, Jun 6 (PTI) The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported the first confirmed death of a human infected with avian influenza A (H5N2), the virus causing bird flu.\n\nThis is the first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally and infection in a person reported in Mexico, the WHO said in a statement.\n\nThe infection was first reported to PAHO/WHO by the Mexico IHR NFP on May 23, 2024. A 59-year-old Mexico resident was hospitalised in Mexico City and had no history of exposure to poultry or other animals, it said.\n\nAccording to the statement, the individual had multiple underlying medical conditions and relatives reported the case to have been bedridden for three weeks, for other reasons, prior to the onset of acute symptoms.\n\nOn 17 April, the individual developed fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea, nausea and general malaise, according to the UN health agency's statement.\n\nHe sought medical attention on 24 April and was hospitalised at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases \"Ismael Cosio Villegas\" (INER) but died the same day due to complications of his condition, the statement said.\n\nThe same day, results from Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR) of a respiratory sample collected and tested at INER indicated a non-subtypeable influenza A virus, it said.\n\nThe sample was on 8 May sent for sequencing to the Laboratory of Molecular Biology of Emerging Diseases Center for Research in Infectious Diseases (CIENI) of INER, which indicated that the sample was positive for influenza A(H5N2), the statement said.\n\nOn 20 May, the sample was received at the Institute of Epidemiological Diagnosis and Reference (InDRE) of the Mexico National Influenza Centre, for analysis by RT-PCR, obtaining a positive result for influenza A.\n\nTwo days later, on May 22, sequencing of the sample confirmed the influenza subtype was A(H5N2), the statement said.\n\nNo further cases were reported during the epidemiological investigation, the agency said.\n\nAffecting the upper respiratory tract, bird flu infections in humans can be mild to severe, sometimes fatal. Symptoms including conjunctivitis and gastrointestinal, have been reported, according to the WHO.\n\nThe viruses responsible for these infections normally spread in animals, but can also infect humans through direct contact with infected animals or contaminated environments, the statement said. Infections in humans have primarily been acquired through direct contact with infected animals or contaminated environments. WHO periodically updates technical guidance protocols for the detection of zoonotic influenza using molecular methods, e.g. RT-PCR. The patient, who had no known exposure to poultry or other animals, developed severe symptoms and died shortly after hospitalization.\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) has confirmed the first human death caused by avian influenza A (H5N2). He was hospitalized with no prior exposure to poultry or other animals.\n\nThe patient, a 59-year-old, had multiple underlying health conditions and was bedridden for three weeks before experiencing acute symptoms, including fever, shortness of breath, and nausea. This is the first time that this subtype has been confirmed to be infecting humans and the first time that an H5 avian influenza virus has been identified in humans in Mexico.\n\n\"WHO continues to emphasize the importance of global surveillance as influenza viruses are constantly evolving,\" the WHO said in a statement. \"This case does not change current WHO recommendations on public health preparedness and surveillance for influenza,\" it added, assessing the current risk to the general public as \"low.\"\n\nAccording to the WHO, the man had been bedridden for three weeks for other reasons before developing acute symptoms, which first appeared around April 17 and included fever, shortness of breath, diarrhea and general malaise.\n\nHe sought medical attention on April 24 and was admitted to the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases in Mexico City. He died the same day.\n\nOther subtypes of H5 avian influenza have infected humans, but past cases suggest the virus \"has not acquired the capacity to be persistently transmitted between humans,\" the WHO said, adding that no people who had come into contact with the man shortly before his death have so far tested positive for the H5N2 virus.\n\nAvian influenza in general Threatening international poultry supplies, There is a risk of infection in humansIt is usually spread through direct contact with infected animals or contaminated environments, and according to the US Department of Health, there are no known cases of people contracting avian flu from eating properly cooked meat. {"uri": "8164831533", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:07:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:07:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:06:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/roberthart/2024/06/06/another-bird-flu-variant-reaches-humans-what-to-know-about-h5n2-after-first-ever-confirmed-death/", "title": "Another Bird Flu Variant Reaches Humans: What To Know About H5N2 -- After First-Ever Confirmed Death", "body": "A man in Mexico died after contracting a strain of bird flu -- H5N2 -- that has never been seen in humans before, and is separate from the strain that is ravaging U.S. dairy cattle, the World Health Organization said on Wednesday, raising questions about the potential risks of another form of avian influenza reaching humans.\n\nGet Forbes Breaking News Text Alerts: We're launching text message alerts so you'll always know the biggest stories shaping the day's headlines. Text \"Alerts\" to (201) 335-0739 or sign up here.\n\nInfluenza is a broad family of viruses that is divided and subdivided into different types based on a variety of viral properties and can generally cause similar disease. Both H5N2 and H5N1 -- the strain spreading through U.S. cattle and occasionally infecting humans at the moment -- are influenza A viruses, which are known to cause seasonal human epidemics and are the only influenza viruses known to cause pandemics as well. The alphanumeric code of H and N are used to subdivide the viruses further according to what kinds of proteins are on the surface of the virus (H represents the protein hemagglutinin and N represents neuraminidase). H5 influenza primarily affects birds and can cause devastating outbreaks in wild and domestic fowl. The viruses have been known to infect other animals as well, including humans. Human cases of H5N1 are uncommon, but do happen, and Oxford University infectious disease expert Sir Peter Horby said there have been more than 900 human cases reported since 1997. For decades now, experts have widely considered the H5N1 strain to be a pathogen of pandemic potential and outbreaks, especially those that infect humans or mammals, are major public health concerns. Until the infection in Mexico, however, H5N2 was not known as a virus that could infect humans.\n\nAs an isolated case, University of Reading virologist professor Ian Jones said \"it is impossible to generalize.\" There are a great deal of unknowns surrounding the H5N2 case and while certainly concerning, experts have stressed it does not give immediate cause for panic. First of all, the person who died had multiple other health conditions, which means \"the role of this virus... cannot be assumed to be directly responsible (for his death) without further investigation,\" said Professor Iain Brown, of Britain's Pirbright Institute. Additionally, while officials say the source of infection is not yet known, surveillance has yet to turn up indications other humans have been infected and experts say it is still likely a spillover infection from animals. \"If there are more human infections with this virus it would become of wider concern, but for now it is a very sad but isolated case,\" said Ed Hutchinson, a senior lecturer at the University of Glasgow in Scotland.\n\n\"It would be reasonable to suppose this is a one-off case of zoonotic transfer with no potential to spread,\" said Jones. \"Unless or until there is evidence of strain adaptation or sustained transmission, the risk to the population is very low,\" Jones added. \"The case should act to reinforce the importance of monitoring and eradicating outbreaks in poultry as soon as they occur.\"\n\nAvian influenza, particularly H5N1, is a major concern to health officials. It is feared as the potential source of a future pandemic, devastating to wild and domestic birds, including the food industry, and capable of spreading among mammals. In recent years, cases have been documented in wild birds and, increasingly, livestock. It has been documented in multiple mammal species as well, including sporadic human cases, and experts are concerned the virus could evolve to spread between mammals without the need for close proximity to birds, a key condition for a pandemic to take off. Outbreaks among cattle and dairy farms in the U.S. in recent months have proven particularly concerning. Increasingly, experts are starting to believe the outbreak is more serious than initially thought, particularly with evidence the virus is spreading between cows and from cows to poultry, and have criticized officials' failure to share crucial information and lax testing requirements, which they claim risks outbreaks growing unnoticed. There have been three confirmed cases of H5N1 among dairy farm workers in the U.S., though it's possible other cases have been missed due to a lack of testing and the possibility of asymptomatic or mild infections.", "source": {"uri": "forbes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Forbes"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influenza_A_virus_subtype_H5N2", "type": {"uri": "8164915075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:01:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:01:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:01:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://latinamericanpost.com/americas/mexicos-first-human-case-of-avian-flu/", "title": "Mexico's First Human Case of Avian Flu", "body": "Mexican health authorities report the first human case of low-pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N2), a development that resonates globally, while emphasizing there is no risk to the public and highlighting extensive epidemiological efforts and international cooperation.\n\nIn a significant display of resilience, Mexican health authorities have confirmed the country's first human case of low-pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N2). This announcement, made in the midst of global concerns about avian influenza and its potential impact on public health, is a testament to the robustness of Mexico's health system. Despite the initial alarm, officials have assured the public that there is no identified risk of contagion, emphasizing the comprehensive measures taken to control and investigate the incident.\n\nThe case involves a 59-year-old man from the State of Mexico who had a history of chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, and long-term hypertension. On April 24, he sought medical attention at the National Institute of Respiratory Diseases' Ismael Cos\u00edo Villegas' (INER) and unfortunately passed away the same day due to complications from his existing health conditions. The initial tests revealed influenza type A, but it wasn't immediately clear which strain he had contracted.\n\nFurther investigation by the Laboratory of Molecular Biology of Emerging Diseases at the INER and the Institute of Epidemiological Diagnosis and Reference (InDRE) confirmed that the patient had contracted the low-pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N2). This marked the first confirmed human case of this particular virus globally.\n\nIn a joint statement, the Mexican Secretariat of Health (SSa), along with the Secretariats of Agriculture and Rural Development (Sader) and Environment and Natural Resources (Semarnat), clarified that no identified source of infection exists and that extensive testing of the patient's contacts yielded negative results.\n\nThe statement highlighted that \"During an exhaustive epidemiological investigation, all samples from identified contacts tested negative.\" Additionally, the SSa has been actively searching for cases of viral respiratory disease and analyzing data to detect any changes in the trends of respiratory illnesses in Mexico City and the State of Mexico.\n\nAvian influenza, commonly known as bird flu, has a storied history in global public health. The first significant outbreak among humans occurred in Hong Kong in 1997, involving the H5N1 strain, which led to extensive culling of poultry to prevent a pandemic. Over the years, various strains of avian influenza have emerged, causing sporadic infections and fatalities among humans, usually those in direct contact with infected birds.\n\nLatin America has not been a significant hotspot for avian influenza compared to other regions, but the recent detection of H5N2 in Mexico highlights the interconnected nature of global health threats. The region's response to such incidents is crucial, given the potential for rapid disease spread in today's globalized world.\n\nIn response to the detection, Semarnat conducted biological sampling and monitoring of wild and synanthropic birds in the Tl\u00e1huac-Xico wetlands and surrounding areas near the patient's residence. This was done in coordination with the National Service for Health, Safety, and Agri-Food Quality (Senasica) to establish a continuous monitoring system for the timely detection of similar cases in wildlife.\n\nThe Mexican government, recognizing the importance of global solidarity in health crises, has actively communicated with international bodies. Operating under agreements like the North American Plan for Animal and Pandemic Influenza (NAPAPI), this collaboration ensures that Mexico's response is not only effective but also aligned with global standards and practices for managing and mitigating the spread of avian influenza. This international cooperation is a beacon of hope in the face of global health threats.\n\nThe Mexican-American Commission for the Prevention of Foot-and-Mouth Disease and Other Exotic Animal Diseases (CPA) has implemented active epidemiological surveillance in backyard poultry areas. This measure, aimed at identifying potential bird cases related to human cases, underscores the crucial role that the public plays in managing health crises. Despite these measures, Mexican health authorities have reassured the public that the risk posed by this virus to the general population is low, empowering individuals to take control of their health.\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) also considers the public health risk from this virus to be minimal. Consequently, consuming well-cooked chicken or eggs is deemed safe and does not pose a health threat to humans.\n\nThe detection of H5N2 in Mexico reminds us of the region's vulnerability to zoonotic diseases and the importance of robust public health systems. Latin America has faced numerous public health challenges, from dengue fever and Zika virus outbreaks to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. These incidents have underscored the need for solid health infrastructure, rapid response mechanisms, and international cooperation.\n\nMexico's response to this avian influenza case reflects a proactive approach that combines local expertise with global best practices. It also highlights the importance of transparency and timely information dissemination in managing public health crises.\n\nHistorically, Latin America has dealt with various infectious diseases, often with limited resources. The response to the H5N2 case is informed by past experiences with diseases like H1N1 influenza, which significantly impacted the region in 2009. The lessons learned from these experiences have shaped current public health strategies, emphasizing the importance of preparedness and rapid response.\n\nThe region's health authorities have become adept at mobilizing resources quickly and coordinating with international partners to contain outbreaks. This capability is crucial in a global health landscape where diseases can cross borders rapidly, necessitating a collective effort to safeguard public health.\n\nConfirming the first human case of low-pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N2) in Mexico is critical in the country's public health narrative. While the initial shock of the news has been tempered by assurances from health authorities about the low risk of contagion, the incident underscores the importance of vigilance and preparedness in the face of emerging health threats.\n\nMexico's comprehensive response, which includes extensive epidemiological investigations, international cooperation, and public reassurance, not only sets a benchmark for handling such cases but also underscores the interconnected nature of global health and the need for robust systems to detect, manage, and mitigate the impact of infectious diseases.\n\nMexico's Economic Challenges Under New President Claudia Sheinbaum\n\nAs Latin America continues to navigate its complex public health landscape, the lessons learned from this case will be invaluable in strengthening regional health systems and ensuring a swift and effective response to future health challenges. The commitment to transparency, thorough investigation, and international collaboration will be vital to protecting public health and preventing the spread of zoonotic diseases.", "source": {"uri": "latinamericanpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "latinamericanpost.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avian_influenza", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": We have already laid off 25,000\" he said.\n\nWhile his austerity measures have been rejected by the political opposition, labour confederations, unions and social organisations, Milei defended them as being necessary.\n\n\"Never has so much been done in six months as we are doing,\" he said. \"We are not only putting the economy in order but we are also ending corruption, and that is why the political sector is raging,\" said Milei. Xinhua\n\nFirst human fatality from H5N2 strain\n\nGENEVA - The World Health Organization said on Wednesday a person in Mexico had died in the first confirmed human case globally of infection with the H5N2 variant of bird flu.\n\nThe patien died after developing fever, shortness of breath, diarrhoea and nausea, had \"no history of exposure to poultry or other animals\" and \"multiple underlying medical conditions\", the WHO said.\n\nMexican health authorities reported the confirmed case of human infection with the virus to the UN health body on May 23, after a 59-year-old was taken to hospital in Mexico City.\n\nThe WHO said the case was the \"first laboratory-confirmed human case of infection with an influenza A(H5N2) virus reported globally.\"\n\nThe source of exposure to the virus was unknown, the WHO said, although cases of H5N2 have been reported in poultry in the country.
